reviewText:
Have you ever wanted to be a rollar-blading punk, rollin' around the city tagging walls, and stickin' it to the man?
No? Maaaan ♥♥♥♥ you get out of here yes you have. This game is known far across the land for it's kickin' soundtrack, beats so thick you could bounce a coin off 'em. Also, it's so old GBA could run it, so don't sweat the specs. Only worry is the keyboard controls suck harder than your EX girlfriend, so grab an Xbox 360 controller and get going.

Now the objective of the game is simple, roll around the city, tag some walls, and keep away from the fuzz. However, this is all done to the sweet sonic sound that will be oozing out of the audio device of your choosing. It also helps that this game has  graphically dated better than you could ever dream of. (Oh snap son.)  You might get one Jet rank on your first playthrough. Might. If you wanna get Jet on every mission you must first study the anicent urban staking gurus.

There are moments where this game gets janky, though. Even with the right controller getting your character to move how you want can be like trying to guide a small badger through a den of hungry lions. Or sorta like that. Only less guiding the badger through the den and more like the badger just ♥♥♥♥♥ing out, The game also lasts about as long as Chaos Knight's mana bar in a teamfight.

HOWEVER. Deep down you know you don't just want this game, you need it. You NEED to grind on that rail, you NEED to tag that wall, you NEED to UNDERSTAND UNDERSTAND UNDERSTAND UNDERSTAND UNDERSTAND UNDERSTAND THE CONCEPT OF LOVE

reviewText:
(Skip down for pros and cons)

Review
Story
The story is pretty simple, you gather a crew and start expanding your turf through your graffiti.
Other crews want to take over your turf and kidnap your dog, while trying to get your dog back you see a black car drop a disc piece, this leads to you collecting the other pieces. Turs out a guy named Goji thinks the disc is something demonic and wants to get it so he can make a pact with a demon. He wants to take down all the graffiti and make it so there are no more skaters/graffiti artists.
He puts Golden Rhino posters all over the graffiti you need to spray graffiti on all of them and show him you aren't scared. After all that it's time to take him on!
You beat him in a final battle and the credits start to roll.

Graphics
The graphics have aged well in my opinion, the game is colorful and the art style really catches your eye.
Some of the effects are pretty well done too.

GameplayThe gameplay is exactly what you would expect from this game. You are rolling around at the speed of sound while tagging graffiti and collecting spray cans so you can tag even more.
The red spray cans refill your health, the yellow spray cans give you 1 spray can and the blue spray cans give you a couple of spray cans. Like it's original name ,,Jet Grind Radio the main focus is grinding and tagging.
You perform cooler tricks the faster you are moving
date:
for example if you are really slow and press the jump button you just do a simple jump but if you are going fast and press the jump button your character performs a trick.
You can clear stages in a simple casual way or you can be the speed runner and just breeze through the level.
You unlock new spray art by finding them around the map. You can customize you tag with letters of your choice or the ones you have unlocked.

Pros:+Nice soundtrack
+Catchy graphics
+Freedom in stages
+Multiple playable characters.
+Good controls (if you are used to them)
+Characters MEW and GUM (rule 34) ;]

Cons:-Shows XBOX 360 controls instead of keyboard keys.
-Freedom in stages (under a time limit). there is plenty of time on the other hand.
-Controls may feel clunky if you are not used to them. (You will get used pretty fast
recommended:
after failing once or twice).

Final Verdict :~~ 9/10

The game is great and it's the most fun I have had in steam since

reviewText:
I bloody loved Jet Set Radio, back in the days of the Dreamcast. Stylistically, it is still a striking product, with an art style distinct enough that it transcends the need to keep up with technological improvements in gaming. This means that graphically, it is still likely to impress, even though the cel-shading technique it pioneered is now ubiquitous and about as surprising to see in a game as a henchman crouched next to an explosive barrel.

The gameplay, however, just doesn't stand up to scrutiny anymore, mainly lending to a control scheme so incredibly archaic and clunky it makes my grandma look like a futuristic ninja. I would liken the controls in this game to trying to pull a pallet of bricks around on sheet ice with a bungee cord. The characters seem to want to deliberately cause rage-induced aneurisms in its players, and repeatedly I swore at my screen as the once-charming little punk skaters fell from bulldings as the ADHD camera spun in circles, desperately indecisive as to what to lock onto. I don't remember it being like this when it came out, but then again we were more patient gamers back then.

And storywise, it's not anything remarkable, but the charm exuding from every pore in this game is enough to make you want to see it through. A typically Japanese touch sees a racially stereotypical dreadlocked black DJ introducing each story beat, but more importantly the incredible soundtrack. The tunes in this game are probably now its main selling point, and well worth the admission price alone if you're into your chunky beats and late 90's sampling. It certainly takes the edge off when you're trying to wrestle the player characters into doing even one thing you've asked them to.

I feel like I've been very negative about this game, but I still love it. The rose tint of nostalgia will certainly help if you've played previously, but I think theres still enough going for this game that it's worth a go for new players looking to take down the Japanese government with inline skates and spray cans.

reviewText: Jet Set Radio was a great game when it came out on the Sega Dreamcast way back in 2000,  unfortunately it may not have aged too well over the years. Some good work has been put into this HD remake. It looks great, the colorful art style really lending itself to crisper textures and higher resolutions, the once awkward camera is greatly improved with the modern innovation of two thumbsticks and the soundtrack (arguably the best part of the game) is there in its entirety.\n\nHowever, gameplay wise it looks poor when held up to the standard of modern games. Its controls can be frustrating and its mechanics border on being repetitive. If you have no nostalgia or cant at least appreciate the games groundbreaking style through its old school jank you'll only be disappointed. And even fans may be better off letting the memory of how awesome this game was remain unspoiled by time. But sometimes a straight adaption of a classic given a nice spit shine is the best  you could hope for and if that's the case then you'll definitely find yourself satisfied.

reviewText:
Difficulty: Just Right
The Bottom Line: Masterpiece/Superb
Score: 9.0

Note: This Game Been Tried Out And Reviewed In Offline Mode or On Another Steam Account And Or Consoles.

Jet Set Radio is an original Dreamcast game came to the PSN, XBLA, and PC digital download.

Jet Set Radio takes place in an alternate Tokyo; Tokyo-to. Tokyo-to is a city where hip-hop/grafitti is the dominant culture and rollerskates are the transportation method of choice, at least amongst the gangs in town. You play as various characters from a local gang known as the GGs. Gameplay is simple. You skate around the city, grinding and jumping, and spray graffiti at marked locations, to assert GGs presence in the streets or wipe out rival gangs

Learning to skate in Jet Set Radio is kind of hard. Controlling your character isn't that intuitive, and accuracy in your movements is very important. There isn't that much lenience. If you screw up, you'll screw up. Sometimes it feels like your character has a mind of its own. Movement is definitely the weakest part of the game, However, the slightly awkward movement didn't stop it from being ridiculously fun. Gameplay is varied and level design is consistently well thought out. There isn't a dull level in the game.

Graphically and artistically, Tokyo-to is represented beautifully. It is clear that meticulous effort was taken in designing the city, which feels very familiar if you've been to Tokyo, but way cooler. This port looks great on the PC. At 1920x1080 it looks awesome thanks to cel-shaded characters and a highly developed cartoon style. Coupled with a very cool, slightly obscure upbeat hip-hop soundtrack, you can get lost in the world for quite some time.

The game has alot of replay value with the unlockables and I find myself playing it over and over even though I have everything unlocked on the Dreamcast.

Overall: Jet Grind Radio/Jet Set Radio remains simply one of the best games I have ever played, on the Dreamcast, if you have a Dreamcast you need to buy it right now. or on the PC but i still recommend it on the DC.
Note: I Love Dreamcast forever,ouh it is still right next to me here by the way

reviewText: Compared to it's successor, this game can easily hold it's own. The only thing lacking is the local co-op concepts they've added to JSRF.\n\nIt's about living the life in Tokyo-to, tagging the streets, listening to the underground pirate radio and dancing even when someone is talking to you. There really is no other game I've seen similar to this. Roller skates are used by each character all the time and cannot be taken off to walk around. This isn't much of an issue as moving about is relatively simple and easy. It gets a bit complicated at certain points when you want to stop as it does take time to come to a full stop from full speed. None the less the game tries it's best to go over the top with what they gave you. Grinding (on rails) is another big aspect to the game. I remember it being a lot easier in JSRF than it is in JSR. In JSRF, you could be near the rail and have a bit of leeway if you missed your mark. In JSR, you have to be pretty precise in your movements to land on top of the area you want to grind. In JSRF, you were allowed to walk into a grind whereas here, you'll need to press jump (A") before you get going. Once you get how the game mechanics work
date: it'll all slowly fall into place. There are times you may find yourself randomly falling off grind rails. This may be due in part that you are actually colliding with something that you should be jumping over. There were certain parts in the game where for the life of me
recommended: I couldn't figure out why my characters would suddenly just stop
hoursPlayed: drop and free fall from a grind. I later noticed that indeed
voteText: you do need to jump over or avoid certain obstacles. This is most notable with power poles. Either than that
helpfulPercent: the grinding is actually pretty smooth and some pretty sick combos/jumps can be made rail to rail.\n\nImagine grinding on a rail
votesHelpful: then riding a billboard
votesTotal: jumping onto a truck and grinding that
votesFunny: then jumping on power lines then finally
commentsCount: grinding on roofs to reach a "tag point" (where you need to graffiti). This is just one of the many possible combos available. Unlike JSRF
column16: you cannot do moves as you are grinding on a rail. Meaning in the newer game
column17: you were able to press x if you were grinding for a while to do a technique on the rail. Here
column18: you are only able to do moves when you are jumping. Moves can be strung together by timing your next jump right. By keeping the timing right
column19: this also let's you keep your momentum and speed. Tagging is a lot more inclusive in this one than JSRF. They will ask you to rotate the stick in all sorts of directions to complete your graffiti art. Bigger murals will take more time
column20: technique and paint. Besides having the basic movements of jumping and tagging
column21: the player may also hit the sprint button ("RT") for a little extra umph while the right stick allows you to move the camera.\n\nFor future Jet Set games
column22: I would recommend adding more actions (such as shouldering people as your moving through an area) or something along those lines. More controls means more action. The story itself is pretty cool and characters are nothing short of creative. It starts out as small time gangs beefing in which it starts to turn into all out war with a certain group of unknowns. When you initially start tagging the streets
column23: police will show up and try to take you down. The first guy is not too bad
column24: but pretty soon you'll have riot police with tear gas
column26: helicopters and even pyromaniacs chasing you down. Although this adds great excitement to the game
column27: there is one great flaw that the other game had that this one didn't : you cannot retaliate! You can't hit back or even tag your enemies to knock them down. If you run into a cop full speed
column28: you'll be taking the brunt of the damage. If you run into another character
column29: they will sort of stumble but your character will feel all the force (especially your health bar). This is the one little thing I couldn't get over as I want to fight back! I know it ain't easy going against tanks but hey
column30: if a little spray paint gets into their engines
column31: I'm sure their check engine lights will go on. You may retaliate to certain extents. There is a level where helicopters will be hovering by power cables in which you can tag them as you pass along (leading to their extermination). The levels try their best to stay diverse and to challenge the player differently. There will be surprise levels where someone will ask to join your squad. You may have to race these people to a tag spot or battle it out with them by tagging their backs. Cops won't always chase you if you manage to reach a safe zone.\n\nLevels at first may seem a bit small
column32: but they've done a hell of a job putting everything together. You will start off small in one area which eventually will allow you to travel to other areas as you progress through the game. You will have to be attentive though as you may have tagged everything in this area
column33: but there is still another area within the city to tag! It's not always super obvious that you are going to the next area. Sometimes it is a bit hard to tell which graphics are simply background graphics and which graphics can lead you to another area. None the less
column34: I think it is great that they decided to make levels interconnected to make them feel bigger. In JSRF
column35: going from place to place is a lot easier than JSR. Red arrows will indicate areas that are needed to be tagged in order to beat the level while green arrows will indicate optional tags (for more points)! An addition this game had that JSRF didn't have was the ability to ride on the back of cars! Don't want to go up a big hill? reviewText: Why is this classic game only three quid normally? When did the price come down so severely? I bought it full price day of launch on the Dreamcast, and again when it came out on Steam at the low low price of £6, and now it's less than a Happy Meal? The game doesn't deserve that - yeah, it may be over twelve years old now, but there's still no other game like it in the world (except its very different Xbox-born sequel, which I hope SEGA will find worthy of a PC release) - it's utterly unique and sublime in its presentation, gameplay, and pacing. If you don't have this game in your library already, there's no excuse now!

So, Jet Set Radio is an amazing game that looks pretty well , the controls are fine, you can even change them yourself, the thing is turning back or doing some extreme curve, it might get a bit annoying on those parts but as much as you play this game you'll get used to it, the graffiti system is nice, but as i dont have a gamepad i cant do most of the graffiti technices that you have to apply such as moving the joystick in a circle shape or half a circle, so i just have to spam the key to graffiti and the moves that i can perform with the keyboard, or do the graffiti till i reach the joystick part then spam the key again, this little issue doesnt let you play pretty well with Yo-Yo as his graffiti technique is his flaw and it requires more ''Joystick action'' but you can still use them to explore and wander around, even finish challenges with those characters but graffiti?, dont mind it much.

How do i explain, HOW AMAZING THE SOUNDTRACK IS?...So anyways, the game is full of secret places and stuff to explore, so sometime you might want to explore every single corner of Tokyo-to, the graphics are fantastic but sometimes you can see unloaded parts of the map from some distance, not everytime, it has a few bugs but they arent game breaking or annoying so you might want to find them yourself.

reviewText:
I just recently played this game for the first time to 100%.  It's been one of the most enjoyable games I've played in a while.

The goal of the game is to tag the biggest marks before the police arrive and escalate in force, and to tag all marks in a timely manner - unless you're hanging around doing sick tricks like Otto Rocket to top that leaderboard.  Levels are divided into sections, but most sections double back on one another, preventing tedium and allowing you to scope out your marks before tagging. Don't be alarmed by how sluggish the controls feel, squid.  They're given such qualities on purpose, and once the controls are understood, they are completely congruous to the level design.  You'll be tricking off of everything.  It will be so great.

Like NiGHTs or Crazy Taxi, there's always room to play better and improve your score, making the game addictive and arcade-like.  Unlike NiGHTs or Crazy Taxi, this is the only one I can stand playing for so long.

The problems with this game are the sometimes-spotty collision detection, the camera (you're given some control but it is never really perfect), and the rival fights.

6.9/7

reviewText:
The music is just as good as it was when this game appeared on the Dreamcast as one member of a magical collective of pure imagination that blinked into the world around the year 2000.  It still looks absolutely fantastic.  The cel-shaded graphics are better than ever: some tweaks make this feel great in high-def.  Not just the style, but the fluid animation, the textures, and the character design are as fresh as ever.  And it has a surprising amount of places to go and things to accomplish.  I remember beating this game.

It also really does validate the existence of its sequel, Jet Set Radio Future.  The level design here is solid, but JSRF really takes it to new heights, and I find myself wanting to play some of those levels.  I also appreciate that they go on to simplify the graffiti mechanic.  The circular motions have always been a little frustrating.  When they work, they're very satisfying—you feel like you've got this DOWN.  When they don't, it feels like it wasn't your fault and it's frustrating.

While the updates to this game aren't massive, they provide a more-than-adequate excuse to buy this on Steam at such a reasonable price, to be able to play instantly. How many people still have their Dreamcasts ready to play?  Kudos to SEGA for releasing this great game at a compelling price.  Hope there's more to come.

reviewText:
Originally created for the Sega Dreamcast back in the year 2000, Jet Set Radio has been brought back out into the wild with a revamped HD version.  Has this game stood the test of time or are things from this era in gaming history best left alone?

The story is a very simple one, you play as a member of the GG's, a group of youngsters in the city of Tokyo-To who fight other groups in the many locations in the game world. Your goal is one of expression through dance, music, and graffiti.

The design of the game is that of a very simple one. Pressed by time you go around tagging up different parts of the city to expand your territory all the while escaping the clutches of the police. The game also invokes a sense of style in how you go about your mission. It isn’t just enough to tag up the city but to make sure you look cool while you do it.

The gameplay is one of an intense cat and mouse. Finding the areas you need to tag while being chased by police, dogs, helicopters, and tanks (not all at the same time, mind you). All the while the sands of father time slip down in the hour glass. But, before you can tag anything you have to gather spray cans which are spread around the different levels. Each of the characters you can choose from has a certain amount of graffiti they can carry as well as a certain amount of health and skill for pulling off tricks. When finding an area in need of some graffiti, you enter into a mode of a series of quick time events. In these events you swing the left analog stick in a specific direction (specific button presses on the keyboard). If you are to mess up the event you lose a can of graffiti in the process, but when you restart you start back at the beginning.

After clearing a section of the game in the single player campaign, levels will become opened to the other three modes of the game.
Jet Graffiti: a mode in which you spray paint (tag) the streets.
Jet Technique: a mode where you earn as many points as you can (i.e. do as many tricks as you can) until time is up.
Jet Crush: in this mode you pick a person from your group to race with someone else in your group.

Bringing in something completely new to the scene (at the time), the game shows off its cell shaded graphics which give the feeling of playing an anime/manga. Accompanying the new graphic style is a diverse array of music ranging from j-pop, hip-hop, funk, electronic dance, rock, and acid jazz. The graffiti in the game was the work done by several artists, most notably Eric Haze who contributed several pieces including the game’s logo.

The game also has a nice level of replayability with online leaderboards for all game modes (including the campaign). Jet set radio also has unlockable characters of the different gangs you go up against, as well as a few other surprises ;].

I would highly recommend this game to any gamer, it just oozes cool.

reviewText:
JET SET RADDDIIOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO!


Since it's beginnings in 2000, the Jet Set Radio series became an instant cult-classic. Fast forwarding to modern times, the gameplay is a bit wonky, and can get some timing to get used to as it was design for the limited hardware and controller of the Dreamcast.

But the cel-shaded graphics still looks good today, and the soundtrack is still timeless. Blending Hip-Hop, Dance, Techno, Jazz, Funk, Rock, Metal, and even Salsa the soundtrack is perhaps one of the best soundtracks you will ever hear let alone in a video game.

For under $10, this a gem that you should buy and experience at least once(you can easily beat it in 5 hours), and perhaps convince SEGA to give this series new life.


JET SET RADDDIIOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO!

reviewText:
Hmm, I remember this game being longer. Maybe it's because it's been over 10 years since it was first released (and I don't remember it correctly), maybe it's because I got used to the controls, I don't know, and it doesn't matter.

This Jet Set Radio isn't a remake of the first game. It's 'just' an HD update. Let me tell you that it looks great in motion, especially in 1080p resolutions or higher. It's simply brilliant. The textures are still the same though. And they haven't aged well. They look really low res at times, which is somewhat disappointing. The controls also haven't been upgraded (camera view aside), but that's not such a big issue since they have always worked properly to begin with. The gameplay itself has been kept intact and it's still as fun and original as it was 12 years ago. It's a mix of (doing tricks while) skating and spraying graffiti, while avoiding the law/enemies and fighting rival gangs for control of the city.

Awesome stuff !

[Rating: 88/100]

reviewText:
This game is easily in my top 10 games of all time. Though my steam hours may be kind of lacking, I've played this game a lot on the Dreamcast. This port is fantastic and playing it in HD is such a joy. But what is it that makes this game so special?

First off, lets talk music. This game has one of the greatest soudtracks of all time. Every song is incredibly varied and every single one will get stuck in your head. Hideki Naganuma created an absolute masterpiece with this soundtrack.

Next thing worth mentioning are the visuals. This game was originally made in the year 2000, thats 14 years ago, and it STILL looks good to this day. Sure, some of the textures may be a bit lacking and objects may seem a bit blocky by today's standarads, but for an HD re-release of a game thats 14 years old, it holds up really well.

The game play is really fun as well. The game has a really good flow to it, seeing as it relys heavily on your momentum. Sure, some say the controls are a bit clunky and the auto-grinding can be a pain sometimes, but once you get used to it, those things stop being an issue (for the most part). Grinding down a railing,, jumping off to wall ride, doing a backflip off of said wall onto another railing, all while spraying graffiti and avoiding helicopter and tank fire still feels as awesome as ever.

With all of this said, I heavily recommend purchising this game, whether you've played the original or not. Maybe if enough of you readers buy it,  sega will put out that Jet Set Radio Future remake we are all waiting for

reviewText:
I haven't even touched Jet Set Radio until just a few days ago, maybe 3 or 4 days before this review, and I regret not getting my hands on it until now. The absolute best part about this game is its design. Between the cel-shading and the vibrant colors, this game is astonishing to look at even with its low-poly models and slightly aged textures. It definitely looks like it's been touched up a bit, and even then the game has aged wonderfully. The soundtrack goes along with its aethstetic perfectly with turntablist hip hop tunes, electronic tracks with backing guitars, and a singular pop-punk track thrown in there for whatever reason, but even that track fits in.

The game's story is simple, nothing notable in the least and most of the time gets over-shadowed by the humorous and lighthearted dialogue in the cutscenes. The gameplay, however, is where the game takes a hit. It's not so much that the game itself is difficult, but it's that the controls are a bit clunky and sometimes frustrating. The way the game punishes you for getting too close to a challenger you're supposed to tag a group or race an opponent is the biggest flaw, with issues like inconsistencies with tricks and enemies that you just can't shake off being minor in comparison. It's easy to get past most of the flaws with a little experience. The game is that it's fairly short with about 6-8 hours of gameplay and a five dollar price tag, it's not that big of a deal in the big picture.

With that said, I think this has to be one of the greatest deals on steam. Five dollars for a completely unique experience you will not get with any other title. Less than most titles on steam, and less than most things period. Buy a copy of this game right now, and maybe buy some copies for your friends. If this game goes on sale for 50% off or less, then buy copies for all your friends. 9/10

reviewText: 8/10 - Jet Set Radio, originally on the SEGA Dreamcast, and called Jet Grind Radio on the Dreamcast in North America, is back! And in glorious HD. Part action/platformer, part in line skate video game, Jet Set Radio is a unique and extremely fun title. One of the first titles to ever use the now common cel-shading graphics, it certainly has a unique visual style, even today. You play as part of a group of young in line skaters, bombing the system by skating around in different urban environments in Tokyo-to, and tagging different areas while running from the local police, and competing with other gangs. Not the type of gangs you'd think of. Just groups of rival graff heads looking to lay stake in different areas by putting up their own signature tags. This game was fresh more than a decade ago, and still a blast to play today. It's also accompanied by an extremely catchy soundtrack filled with artists ranging from genres of J-Pop, underground hip hop, and more. This version features nearly all of the music featured in both the PAL and North American versions. The 1 Japanese only track is still missing from the game.

reviewText:
One of the best, if not the best game I've played on the Dreamcast.

While a controller is not required to play this game, some may find keyboard controls to be inconvenient, although I can use them fine, it just takes a little getting used to.

Includes the levels and music which used to be exclusive to the North American Dreamcast release of the game, which was titled Jet Grind Radio. With Jet Set Radio's Steam release, the once-exclusive content is now available for everyone.

The game has been remade in HD, which from what I can tell, this simply means that the game was increased in resolution to look suitable on HD widescreens. The assets as far as I can tell are untouched. (Which is a good thing to me.)

Features an incredible soundtrack, one of the best I've heard in a video game.

Has a fair amount of replay value in trying to achieve Jet ratings on all the levels, unlocking all the characters, collecting all the Graffiti Souls, and unlocking the achievements.

If you didn't play Jet Set Radio back then, you might not like it today, which is what I believe caused the sudden surge in negative reviews since the game became free on February with the Make Love Not War event. It's a 16 year old game, and some would find it to be outdated by today's standards. Do some research and see if it's a game in which you're interested.

If you're like me and liked Jet Set Radio back then, you'll most likely love it today as myself and many others do, and I'd definitely recommend it on Steam, with all the new features and improvements. I got it for free with the Make War Not Love event on Steam, so in no way whatsoever can I complain.

reviewText:
Never played the game before, so nostalgia doesn't influence this review.

This game is great.

It looks wonderful (16 years after its release) and it sounds wonderful (gotta love that funky turntablism japanese soundtrack).

Some people say the controls are clunky : there're not.
Actually the game is hard, so you have to git gud. It may seem awkard at first, but you'll get used to it in a few hours.

The story mode is quite short (6 hours), but trying to get Jet ranking on every level is the real challenge.
That was my favorite part because it was hard enough to be gratifying, and I got good enough to enjoy doing it (riding through the city is a blast when you know how to handle the game).

Try to invest some time in this game : it's worth it.

reviewText:
A cool arcade-style game. Skate and grind around different parts of Tokyo-to while spraying grafitti all over the place. Easy to learn, but takes dedication to master the grinds and execute the spraying. Avoid police and later mafiosi and spread glorious youth culture.

The soundtrack is one of the best ever I have ever heard, outstanding, like the graphical style. It uses cel-shading, I think it might have been the first game ever to use it back on the Dreamcast. It's cleaner and crisper in the HD version.

3D platformer mixed with skating mechanics, all presented with an unique graphical style, amazing soundtrack and a colourful cast of characters create a game unlike any other. High replayability for prefectionists and completionists.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Jet Set Radio is a stylized masterpiece from the little known console known as the Dreamcast. It was one of the very first games to use cell shaded graphics. Which it uses to build it's aesthetic of a futuristic Tokyo. The goal of the game is to hit various parts of this futuristic city and tag them up with graffiti while avoiding the corrupt police officers when they send the friggen army in to take you out.

There are very clearly influences given from games like Tony Hawk's Pro Skater. Though that game was very much focused on it's tricks and scoring. With this game, great preference is given to it's aesthetic and especially it's soundtrack.

While I consider it's successor on the original Xbox; Jet Set Radio Future to be superior. Jet Set Radio is still an alright game. Just remember to buy a gamepad if you do wanna play it since the keyboard controls are simply horrible.

reviewText:
PROS:
The Soundtrack is absolutely amazing.
The character designs are well thought out.
The story is pretty darned good.
A game that anyone of any age (able to wield a controller and know how to read of course) can play.


CONS:
The controls are wonky as all hell, honestly. It's pretty difficult. Don't skip the main screen right away, because the game itself will say the controls are those of an Xbox controller. (WASD or the up, down, right, left arrow to move, right button on a mouse to speed up, click the scroll button on a mouse to spraypaint, etc it's weird and annoying in the very beginning.)
The characters, considering this is an old game, are scary sometimes. Prof. K scares me.

4.99 for this classic? It's an amazing deal and so much fun.

reviewText:
PC Port Report

All PC specific settings are configured in a launcher.

DRM
Steamworks

Anti-Aliasing
2x 4x 8x MSAA supported

Framerate
Locked at 30fps

Controller
Xbox360 controller supported. Recommended due to graffiti input, though keyboard functions fine. Please note that the 'Graffiti action' button also resets the camera. This can not be changed and can be a great annoyance.

Aspect Ratios (widescreen)
16:9, 16:10 and 4:3 supported

Resolutions
From 480p to 1200p at least

Runs in Window
Supported

Rebindable keys
Supported

Textures
Aside from the menu/user interface nothing seems noticeably enhanced from the original Dreamcast game.

3d Models
Dreamcast original models. Unchanged.

Soundtrack
2 songs missing (from the PAL version) Yappie Feet" and "Many Styles".


If I missed anything please let me know in the comments below!"

reviewText:
JET SET RADIO-O-O-O-O-O-O-O-O-O-O-O-O-O-O!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

reviewText: The game itself is the same as it always was, so if you liked it before, you'll like it now. It also looks a lot better running at higher resolutions with AA. Like a lot of the other Dreamcast ports though, it either works for you or it doesn't, and Sega's budget for post-release patches seems to be minimal. Many people don't have problems, but I had to use a fan-made patch to the .exe to un-cap the framerate, or else it would run at 7.5fps in super slow motion, then a third-party program to lock it back down to 30fps or it'd run too quickly. It's enough of a hassle that, along with the random crashes, I lost interest pretty quickly. Some of their other ports have worked fine for me when they've given other people problems though, so it's kind of hit or miss. Do you feel lucky?

reviewText:
Jet Set Radio was a revolutionary game in a lot of ways - style, gameplay, graphics. I've bought this game on at least three different systems over the years. It's a cult classic and definitely worth trying if you've never had the opportunity to.

The camera and controls might not be as tight on something released today, but this game is still a heck of a lot of fun! Viva la Dreamcast!

EDIT: Worth mentioning is that this port is done right on PC! You can play at 1080p and tweak the visuals to improve them far over what was available on the Dreamcast! There's also a nice mini-documentary about the game included as a bonus feature!

reviewText:
There are a few games that I was sad to never have played in my childhood; there are some Pokemon games, some Zelda games, a few Final Fantasy games, but among that list is Jet Set Radio.  Seeing it for a really low price on the HumbleBundle website, I shrugged and bought it on a whim.  I am proud to say that this game has won me over.
The plot is pretty straightforward.  You're part of an inline skating gang that is trying to win the city of Tokyo-to via tagging.  You have to deal with rival gangs and police.  Sounds pretty simplistic and boring, but I think it's far from that.
The soundtrack is awesome and won me over the minute the first song came on.  The environments, for a game that was first released in 2000, look really nice.  The gameplay itself is really fun, jumping around the environments and evading your enemies whilst trying to completely cover the area in colour, and I also took a liking to the characters almost immediately.
The story is a bit lacking, but to be fair it's really not something that you focus on compared to the ever-so-enjoyable gameplay.  So what are you waiting for?  Get the damn game!!

reviewText:
One of THE games of my nostalgic Dreamcast-era. By that I mean it is one of my favorite games of all time that left an unwashable trace inside me for being of the best and rad games of that time as a crazy stylish roller-blading simulator AND at the same time a graffiti artist always on the run.
It was a tremendously fun game then and it still is, a port or not a port (which is surprisingly not badly done at all).
Not to mention a soundtrack I used to listen many many times all over across a span of many years (and rollerskate listening to it too haha, along with Air Gear ost).
The title is hilarious and unique in many ways. A masterpiece in my eyes.
Recommended for every rollerblades, graffiti, quirky art style, nice electro music or just funny outlaw action lovers.
P.S. An analog stick is highly recommended, graffiti painting is done by rotating the analog a lot and it is crucial. Can be done with a keyboard but it's pretty laggy and unreliable in my opinion.

reviewText: EDIT: I've been told that there is an option to make it so the camera doesn't center when you spray tags. I will edit again once I verify that to be true.\n\nThis is overall a good game and I like it a lot, but it must be said that the controls are kind of bad. Mainly the directional inputs when jumping and the fact that the spray graffiti button also centers the camera (this remake adds camera control to the right stick, yet this annoying feature remains). The latter can't be fixed, but for the jumping, make sure that if you need to jump to the side less than 45 degrees, that you jump first then fine tune your direction while you are in the air. It's not for everyone, but it is completely playable once you learn to work with the controls.

reviewText:
Jet Set Radio is much like the Tony Hawk's series, in that it has an arcade type gameplay to it.
The graphics are pretty, vibrant and well distributed among the very different locations of the game.
It's all around an amazing game, and more people should play it.
Gameplaywise the game uses an automatic combo mechanism that for the time of it's original release was really uncommon.
This doesn't affect the gameplay, because the game has it's own style and charm which really fits the choice of controls.

P.S: I would be really happy to play Jet Set Radio Future, but it's not on Steam so it may be time to port it to the PC don't you guys think?

P.P.S: I played this game when I was 3 years old and I remember the whole game, ah sweet dreamcast...
I don't know why, but it's that good of a game to stuck to a 3 year old's brain.

My score for this game is a 10/10.

reviewText:
This review will be mostly negative but stick through it, I'll sing this game's praises soon enough. First off I'd like to say what a disappointment this port is on a technical level. Stuttering textures and cut off sound bites are all throughout the game, and though the last time I play JSR was 10 years ago, I think I can safely say I don't remember these issues on the Dreamcast version. There's also a bug where your game might not be able to save, but will indicate that it has, which is only fixable by editing the hex values of the game's executable (where it turns out one instance of the word SAVE should be lowercase).

Despite the incompetence of whoever allowed these bugs to blight such a colorful weave in the tapestry of gaming history, JSR still fares okay. The art style is vibrant and colorful, there's excellent music that fits the tone perfectly, and the world it presents is interesting and lively. In fact, the game's flair is essentially it's only selling point, as the gameplay is stiff and feels alien to control, like your actions have a hard time corresponding to your key presses, messing up the energetic flow that every other part of the experience is trying to create.

You'll be cruising down Benten-Cho with Miller Ball Breakers thumping rhythmically; you're getting all pumped and ready to do some nice tricks, but you get snagged on wayward geometry or land one micrometer away from the rail you were trying to stick because despite the cartoony art style and space physics, JSR can require almost real-life skating precision sometimes. It's frustrating and it takes way too long to recover from bailing, which wouldn't be so bad were it not for the missions being timed and often involving chases. The controls are so jerky it's actually somehow preferable to play on a keyboard, which I didn't think was possible with a skating game.

It's a game of missed potential, but is still worth a buy just to get entrenched in the youthful, rebellious atmo, and get a handle on what the Dreamcast brought to the table as a launch title, so there's a historic glimmer to it that way.

5/10

reviewText:
Skating trick game with graffiti objectives.

Gameplay is fun and satisfying especially coupled with the legendary soundtrack, I always feel happy playing this or any game with the JSR soundtrack.
The levels start off fairly simple but have a good difficulty curve that really demand some level of planning and skill by the second half of the game.

Very stable considering it's a 2000 console port. Only ever crashed once for me, everything else has been fine, no slowdown even on a mediocre PC. Gamepad is almost mandatory due to the control scheme, but I'm sure some people will be able to use keyboard if they really want to.

10/10 would ride high on a smooth stream of supersonic sound again

reviewText:
Though not as polished as JSRF, the original Jet Set Radio still kicks an incredible amount of ♥♥♥. It is the symbol of the Dreamcast era of SEGA for a reason.
First of all, the graphics aged well, thanks to cel-shading (arguably, this game invented cel-shading) and an awesome artist work. If you can appreciate the great style over the amount of polygons per model, you're going to enjoy how this game looks even today.
The soundtrack is all kinds of awesome. I don't think anything needs to be said here.
The gameplay however, is the reason why I would take JSRF over this one. The controls could be wonky at times, the tutorial is borderline impossible to complete because of one needless challenge at the end, and also the time limit will make you rage at one point or another. And overall, Jet Set Radio is not as smooth as it's sequel. Well, after all, this game turns 14 soon.
JSR is still one of my favorites, and still is a classic. If you consider yourself a true gamer, you need to check this out.
P.S. It would be great if SEGA ported JSRF here (since it was an XBOX exclusive, sadly), it would make me the happiest person ever.

reviewText:
So, Jet Set Radio is a...... sorta kinda... an action (sports) game ?
Where you control a member of some kind of graffiti gang, and spraying the graffiti all over the town, while being chased by tank and helicopter, just for a simple act of vandalism !?
The gameplay itself kinda resembles Tony Hawk, not as free as tony hawk, since in here, we're given a direct objectives in each stage, there's also a time limit. Still pretty nice though ! Now on to the review.

(+)
- AWESOME MUSIC, the music is, just incredibly masterpiece. Probably the most important fact here !
- You can get a long playtime for a cheap price !
- This game is pretty challenging. The difficulty is just right imo. Sometimes it can be annoying to repeat a single level over and over again. But, when you managed to finish it, man. The happiness is real.
- GUM.

(-)
- The controls on keyboard+Mouse is... not really comfortable imo, i suggest you to play with controller.
- The camera is kinda hard to control sometimes, or maybe it's just me.
- The tutorial is kinda bad, i can't seems to finish it even though i already followed the instruction.

This game is totally worth it, mate. This game itself is a HD remake from 16 years old game, so maybe the graphic isn't really that great, but still. the gameplay, and the music will totally compensate for that. GET ITTT ! C:

reviewText:
Jet Set Radio is an extremely interesting game that has recieved much attention over the years. It is a rather fun game, but at the same time the game suffers on many different levels.

The gameplay of Jet Set Radio is rather interesting. You play as part of a group of Punks that decide to graffiti areas of the town you are in. You do this by rollerblading across maps of varying length, depending on the stage and how late in the game you are.  Its a rather refreshing game, because it isn't seen too much in games. However, the game is mainly split into two different parts as a result of the two extremely different styles of gameplay. The graffiti painting is extremely shallow as a mechanic, because you just move the joystick in a certain direction as a quicktime event. However, the directions you move the joystick in is the same for every single piece of graffiti you paint. It becomes quite tiring because halfway through the game you will probably have the patterns down by muscle memory, and it becomes rather a pain to have to move the joystick in the same directions every time. The game would have benefitted from having you move the stick inn a different direction, or having different patterns. Otherwise the graffiti spraying just becomes you moving the stick as fast as you can while still being slow enough for the game to register you starting the pattern. However, the patterns you follow change depending on the character you pick, so you can choose a different character

In terms of the rollerblading, it requires you to be good at the game if you want to get far.  Whenever you start moving, you start out at a very slow pace. To be able to get to a decent speed (to where you can actually grind on rails), you neet to press a button. However, there is absolutely no reason to not be pressing this button every single time you are on the ground. It would have been much better if they had made you speed up by default when you are on the ground.

There are two main types of special moves" you have in terms of rollerblading. Other than just moving and jumping you are able to grind on rails and jump off of walls. Jumping off of the walls actually is much easier than it seems at first

reviewText:
Jet Set Radio is a game where you play as the GGs, a set of 'rudies' who graffiti the city of Tokyo-to, a spinoff of Tokyo. The game revolves around you performing tricks, but mainly spraying graffiti at certain points. The small graffiti just ask you to press a button to spray, but larger spray tags, named large or extra-large sprays, require you to perform quick time events with the analog stick (or keys if you played on keyboard, like I did).

The game features 4 rival 'teams', the first 3 are the Love Shockers, Noise Tanks and Poison Jam, and then finally the Golden Rhinos. The first 3 are just rival gangs which you are targeted with spraying over their tags while the police stop you from doing so, which leads to the captain Onishima leading a SWAT team, Helicopters, Air Squads, Tanks, Guard Dogs and even more to stop you. Eventually, after beating all 3 teams, the Golden Rhinos then make an appearance.

The story is silly and is quite fun to play with. The game is generally quite fun and easy unless you plan to go for Jet ranking on all levels, unlocking all the characters and graffiti in the game.

The game is definitely worth playing and buying, but hopefully in the future we'll get the sequel Jet Set Radio Future.

reviewText:
Prior to picking up Jet Set Radio for free on Steam I've had the priviledge to play Jet Set Radio Future, which is pretty much a reimagining of this one. Jet Set Radio gave me a unique and interesting, colorful story regarding gang rivalries and the exploration of graffiti as an artform, as told by the mad DJ, Professor K.
Jet Set Radio Future visuals are stylistic and has been able to stand the test of time. The game is accompanied by fun and catchy electronic rap songs and an almost perfect, fluid control scheme. To say the least about JSRF's gameplay is: If you messed up on a jump or trick then it was most likely your fault.
When I started up Jet Set Radio I expected it to be worse than JSRF in all these aspects. I was proven wrong. Jet Set Radio feels almost on par with Jet Set Radio Future, while lacking in some areas of course.

Jet Set Radio:
Pros:
+ Interesting and colorful story that keeps you engaged
+ Fun and catchy soundtrack
+ Diverse cast of characters with different skill sets
+ Engaging challenges per level
+ Professor K
+ Professor K's voice

Cons:
- Time Limit on Missions
- Controls and sprays can be confusing and clunky if you play with a keyboard
- Xbox 360 Controller recommended for maximum enjoyment
- A good port in everything besides controls

Overall:
While the controls hold the game back to a certain extent it can still be enjoyable. I'm loving it so far and I'm sure you will too!

reviewText:
A forgotten gem from the Dreamcast era, now back and polished with HD graphics!

Jet Set Radio was a truly stylish and unique game for its time (in fact it still is today, save for its sequel) and I have to say that while its in-game mechanics, the freedom it gives you and its length are kind of lacking for today's standards, it still remains a great and fun game (though it can get a bit annoying at times, for difficulty related reasons)!

The graphics and backgrounds were already good, but with the HD upgrade they are now great, full of vivid colors and vitality, it is not by sheer luck that Cel Shaded graphics were popularized by this game.

The soundtrack is equally awesome, filled with many kinds of music genres, mostly of japanese and american provenience and pretty much helps set the tone and atmosphere of the game.

The story isn't much, it plays mostly like a parody movie, but for a game like this it isn't expected to, instead, it is filled with many humorous and witty lines, spoken from the mouth of DJ Professor K.

All in all, despite the years on its back, this is still a very fun one-of-a-kind game and as such I urge all of you to try it sometime. It already is cheap and on sales it's even cheaper!

Hopefully Sega will someday remember and decide to give us an HD port of the game's sequel, Jet Set Radio Future, originally available on the first Xbox, since I had found that to be bigger in everything (graphics, soundtrack and open world) and not that much dated compared to today's games!

The Dreamcast era, my favorite gaming era, is sadly over, but it's thanks to HD Ports like this that it continues to live... and with the now announced revival of Shenmue 3 (google it if you don't know what it is, we are talking about my absolute favorite games ever) all I can say is... long live childhood years!

reviewText:
Jet Set Radio	 Review
Plot Summary	The game is set in Tokyo-to and you're intoduced to the events happening in this city by Professor K, the DJ of a pirate radio station (Jet Set Radio).
The city is split into three parts, Shibuya-cho, Kogane-cho and Benten-cho
The game begins with a 17 years old ''Rudie'' (Skater that expresses himself through graffiti) named Beat founding his own gang named GG which is short for Graffiti Gang.
During the course of the game you will encounter with alot of rival gangs trying to get into your territory or provoking you to go into their turf.
You will also encounter a few Rudies that want to join GG. Not so fast though, they will only join if you beat them in a tag race or perform the tricks they show you.

The plot is a solid  8/10 because it's not meant to be serious, it's meant to be simple and punkish.

Gameplay
The game mainly revolves around skating in your rollerblades and tagging graffiti with alot of grinding.
It's pretty simple but doing tricks is really satisfying.
In order to tag a bigger graffiti you have to do quick-time events (which are implemented pretty well in this game).
If you play with an Xbox360 controller, RT is used to perform a dash, jumping on a rail to grind while dashing makes you grind faster and jump further.
You have to evade police and face other gang members through out the levels.
There are alot of unlockables and collectibles to keep the replay value high.
Controls may be clunky at times.

Gameplay is  9/10  and would've been a solid  10 if it wasn't for the clunky at times controls.

The GraphicsOne of the first games to use cel shading and I must say it's done really well in this game.
It looks impressive even today.
The graphics fit perfectly with the theme of the game.

SoundtrackThe soundtrack is a big part of the game since the whole game has rhytm (Your gang dances to the music in the character selection screen).
It's really catchy and upbeat.
It's produced by Hideki Naganuma who is responsible for alot of Sonic soundtracks and for composing the soundtrack of the new Jet Set Radio inspired Hover: Revolt of Gamers.
I personally love the music.

The soundtrack is a solid10/10 and I stay behind this rating... hear it for yourselves.

Final Verdict  9.2/10
The HD port of an old Dreamcast game still holds up really well even today.

reviewText:
Classic. A unique charming experience that every gamer should try at least once.
The visual style and music are very engaging, and the gameplay (while difficult on occasion) is satisfying and fun.
When I first played this as a young man, I was completely blown away.

Controls can be a bit janky, and not all of the original songs have been included, but still a wonderful game.

reviewText: Моя самая первая и самая любимая cellshading-овая игрушка.Одна из лучших игр на Dream'e.Яркая,пёстрая,живая и динамичная,с неповторимой атмосферой и игровым стилем.Сюжетик хоть и довольно банальный,но его подача достойна похвалы.Местный диджей так и сыпет харизмой.А эти вставки между уровнями,просто очень крутые...И всё под отличную музыку,идеально вписывающуюся в антураж этого мирка.Далеко не бомжовскую кстати,даже Rob Zombie есть :D.Геймплэй очень простой-катаемся и красим,попутно делая трюки и доставляя массу неприятностей местным властям.Чем техничней и безупречней вы проходите уровень-тем больше очков вам начислят,тем лучше будет оценен ваш скилл.Игра не даёт расслабиться,руки здесь постоянно заняты,вечно что-то крутишь и зажимаешь.Лучше всего играть с джоем,на клавиатуре проблематично красить,но выкрутиться всё же можно.После прохождения сюжета в игре есть чем заняться-половина персонажей как правило не открыта,да и души графити" спрятаны в хитрожопых местах.\nК сожалению

reviewText: Ah, Jet Set Radio.  One of my favorite games from my childhood - back then, it was a game like no other - and that still stands today.  The visuals have aged very well and the graphics look great in HD.  The soundtrack is also as amazing as ever (Naganuma is some kind of a genius), even though a few songs were cut.  The gameplay is fun and challenging - I don't remember it being this hard!  The main thing that could have been changed during the port is the controls.   It plays exactly like it did on the Dreamcast.  Keyboard movement is restricted to 8 directions (like the Dreamcast D-Pad) and an external analog stick isn't much better.  Getting used to movement with a Dualshock 3 was rough, especially with how difficult the game is naturally.  Steam Achievements is a nice bonus as well  Still totally recommend if you were a fan of the original Dreamcast release!  Hoping a JSRF port is in the future!

reviewText: Absolutely incredible. Visual presentation is marvelous, soundtrack is incredible. It's better than the PS3 and Xbox 360 versions of this Dreamcast classic in that the soundtrack is dynamic, meaning it changes every stage, not just looping one song constantly. Also, the graphics and fluidity of the game is all its own for PC. The keyboard and mouse controls aren't impossible, but they're incredibly challenging. I recommend a game controller, BUT, it's not unplayable with keyboard and mouse. You just need to work with it, or if you've played this a ton in the past, you'll adapt fairly fast. Overall: 9/10, highly recommend

reviewText:
It's entirely possible I say this looking through my standard internet issue nostalgia goggles, but Jet Set Radio is just a fun, satisfying game for me. Only real concern with the gameplay I have is that while the skating segments are all rather fluid and fast-paced, grafitti placement is handled through awkward and imprecise QTEs. I'd reccomend playing the sequel, Jet Set Radio Future, if you're looking for an overall more fast-paced, consistent game.

But regardless, the original Jet Set Radio just caries that typical feeling of endearing oddity to me, so maybe it will to you.

Also there's not a single thing stopping you from making all your tags giant ♥♥♥♥♥ and swear words if you so desire.

reviewText:
The originality and fun is what embodies the dreamcast spirit. In the few years active the dreamcast library got flooded by great, original and exclusive games. This is one of them.


No game has such a vivid cartoon feel, look and sound, wrapped in a crazy interpretation of tokyo. The arcade-like gameplay suits the design choices perfectly and it's great.

(The gameplay is actually more like a vehicle to the real purpose of the game, which is to immerse players in the developers idea of Tokyo in the 90's. But this is my interpretation after completing the game dozens of times.)

JSR/JSRF are cult classics from the culmination of a not so far bygone age. An age where SEGA was a force to reckon in video games. Where creativity left no space for remakes, remasters and sequels. A place where video games' pririty was to be fun, entertraining and rememberable.

For the price of this good port it's a no-brainer for old dreamcast owners and new gamers alike.


TLDR: it's a fun game made by fun people, for the entertainement of other people.

*obligatory remark: NOW PORT JSRF!

reviewText:
Jet Set Radio may be one of the weirdest, albeit most unique, games you've ever played.
You control characters on inline skates and go around levels tagging (ie: spraying graffiti) various things throughout the level, while avoiding local law enforcement.

The whole setting of the game is filled with bright colours, lots of stylized, zany artistic design, and bad voice acting.

It's decent to play through, but playing this game makes me want to go back and play Tony Hawks Pro Skater 3 for faster-paced, more fun action.

reviewText:
I got this for free from SEGA's 'Make War Not Love' promo along with their other games so I am not going to write anything about the price.

I picked up this game to grab a couple of achievements and wound up playing up to where I am done with it.

This game dates back to 2000 so the graphics may look a little cheesy and out-of-place in 2012 standards when this game was launched on Steam. But with that aside, it's a great game. By great I mean there are lots to do, plenty of achievements (30 to be exact) and a highly challenging gameplay, which is always a plus.

Couple of negatives to be addressed however. The tricks that are performed while spray painting, which is a very pivotal role in the game can be difficult when using a keyboard. A controller is highly recommended if you want to play optimally. The button sprites on dialogues are based on controller buttons and not the keyboard, but upon launching the game, you can customize the controls using different keys anyways.

Tbh, It's not one of those games where I WANT to play it after a long day of work or school since the gameplay becomes somewhat redundant later on. I only pick it up when there's absolutely nothing to do or if you're one of those people that HAVE to play every game in your library, go for it. I recommend at least trying it.

reviewText:
I'm giving this a positive review, and the truth is I thoroughly enjoyed it. But I feel that the flaws should be pointed out first.

- The last level of the game gave me motion sickness. For the first time I can remember, and possibly the first time ever. I am NOT prone to motion sickness, AT ALL, and the last level of this game made me want to hurl.

- The port to computer is not the best because they just directly mapped controller buttons to keyboard keys. This means that people playing on a computer have a serious disadvantage at things like graffiti, where the simple action of move the stick in a circle" becomes "hit WASDWASDWASD as fast as you can until the game decides that you did a circle instead of up-then-right-then-down-then-left separately."

- This game is extremely difficult to play with a laptop touchpad instead of a mouse. (It is playable -- just difficult.)

- The storyline was maybe a little weak? Don't play this for the storyline
recommended:
now on to the positives!

- GREAT music. A+.

- Large levels that you can spend ages exploring. Hidden paths

reviewText:
To anyone who loves classic funky music and is also complete weaboo trash, this game is for them! I had heard so much about JSR so I finally decided to buy it and as you can see from my hours I really loved it.

The only real con I can think of is the keyboard controls, they´re not bad and I was still able to 100% the game with them...but they´re a little awkward and makes sticking some moves frustrating as hell at first, but just play around a little bit and it becomes less and less of a problem!

The story is simple yet fun, the characters are memorable, the music is incredible and will be in your head for hours, and the gameplay is fun and creative. Even if you hate the story and everything about the characters, grinding down a rail while getting chased by a missle listening to a song about mario bros is just too damn fun.



9.8-10 in my opinion, I just can´t wait until they port JSRF!

reviewText:
If you had a dreamcast, you had this groovy game.

It's great to be able to play this game again with HD graphics, listening to its awesome soundtrack and hearing DJ professor K once more.
It's a shame that the framerate is capped at 30 FPS but I really liked the inclusion of the bonus JSRF songs and the BTS video.
The achievements require skill and it’s not just “play the game ‘till the end”.

I wouldn't say this is a game for everyone though: the controls take A LOT of getting used to (even with a gamepad) and the levels at the end can be pretty difficult and annoying (looking at you golden rhinos), but it’s still pretty fun.

Pretty cheap for such a great game, a nice deal if you ask me.

So, Sega… umm, where’s JSRF HD?

reviewText:
The style, art, and music have held up well but the gameplay has become a victim of Father Time.

This was a fun romp down memory lane for me as I grew up in a household that had a SEGA Dreamcast. But beyond former fans of the game I would have a hard time outright recommending this title. The very simple gameplay was unique for it's time but over the course of 15years has become a bit clunky and aged. The quicksand feel of freeskating and your limited abilities can be downright infuriating in the late levels. But I pushed on because I had beat it as a much younger human so gosh darn it I could beat it as an old boring dude!

The charm is all still there. The music, the early cel-shading, the unique setting, the era vibe, etc. It has all held up great and brought warm memories. Combine that with the low low lowww sale prices this game can be found for (down to the price of FREE). And I can still recommend this. Heavy warning for the younger crowd or people who never played it on SEGA Dreamcast though; That gameplay really hasn't held up and it'll be a departure from what you're used to.

Some final technical notes; I played with a 360 controller so I cannot vouch for the keyboard controls but I feel comfortable urging controller use. Can't imagine trying that with a keyboard... Also, this IS locked at 30 frames per second but like some other older games its performance is tied to the frame rate and cannot be changed. This is actually a time where a port gets a pass in this regard. You won't find (or need) any video settings beyond resolution. And finally the bonus content is appreciated (extra music, mini documentary).

Grind a rail for me.

reviewText:
JET SET RADIOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO!!! One of the most phenomenal games I've ever played! Music, colors, and a cartoony style to keep your attention while trying to save your way of life from corrupt corporate business, over the top police, and rival street gangs. This game is nothing but good times and pure fun for all! My only dislikes are: Clunky PC controls (Take some getting used to. It'd be easier to buy a controller.), Locked FPS at 30 (Not a big deal with me to be honest), Sometimes the timer can be a bother, (Combo's race is also kind of lame), and...wait, when's future coming to steam?




oh, right.

Other than that, this game is perfect. I'm working on my 3rd playthrough at the moment and going for a 4th. This game is awesome.

reviewText:
First off anyone who wants to get this game READ THIS OTHERWISE YOUR GAME WILL NOT LOAD SAVED GAMES http://steamcommunity.com/app/205950/discussions/0/617320628124333480/

With that out of the way Jet Set is one of my personal favorite pop in play games. It is very simple and easy to learn but mastering the movements can be trickey. The characters are on roller blades and feel like it so they are limited by that kinda movement in terms of turning and speed in areas such as stairs sharp turns and so on. Keep this in mind while playing because you will fall...a lot. The game is VERY strict on it's physics(which is kinda funny for a pre-physics era game) The over the top and zanny nature of the game it's self keeps it really fun as well as the cops tactics changing from stage to stage.

Personally I recommend this game BUT DOWNLOAD THAT FIX. I have no idea why Sega has not fixed it themselves but thankfully some nice PC modders made a simple fix(All you gotta do is drag and drop)

reviewText:
If you had a dreamcast, you had this groovy game.

It's great to be able to play this game again with HD graphics, listening to its awesome soundtrack and hearing DJ professor K once more.
It's a shame that the framerate is capped at 30 FPS but I really liked the inclusion of the bonus JSRF songs and the BTS video.
The achievements require skill and it’s not just “play the game ‘till the end”.

I wouldn't say this is a game for everyone though: the controls take A LOT of getting used to (even with a gamepad) and the levels at the end can be pretty difficult and annoying (looking at you golden rhinos), but it’s still pretty fun.

Pretty cheap for such a great game, a nice deal if you ask me.

So, Sega… umm, where’s JSRF HD?

reviewText:
To anyone who loves classic funky music and is also complete weaboo trash, this game is for them! I had heard so much about JSR so I finally decided to buy it and as you can see from my hours I really loved it.

The only real con I can think of is the keyboard controls, they´re not bad and I was still able to 100% the game with them...but they´re a little awkward and makes sticking some moves frustrating as hell at first, but just play around a little bit and it becomes less and less of a problem!

The story is simple yet fun, the characters are memorable, the music is incredible and will be in your head for hours, and the gameplay is fun and creative. Even if you hate the story and everything about the characters, grinding down a rail while getting chased by a missle listening to a song about mario bros is just too damn fun.



9.8-10 in my opinion, I just can´t wait until they port JSRF!

reviewText: Let me start by saying Jet Set Radio is the predecessor to one of my favorite games of all time. So I'll admit I'm a bit biased when talking about the series. Jet Set Radio (or Jet Grind radio) is originally a Dreamcast game published by SEGA that came out in 2000. And is basically the game that started cel-shaded graphics. The game takes place in the fictional city Tokyo-to where skater youth gangs tag the streets on their futuristic as ♥♥♥♥ roller blades. The gameplay consists of Skating, Grinding and spray painting, this is all rather enjoyable when you're not battling the controls which is where the game shows it's age a little. I won't lie there's a certain amount of precision required here that most skate games don't share, this can lead to frustration at times but after prolonged exposure and a better understanding of the movement system this becomes less of an issue. This does add a certain level of challenge that can feel very rewarding when you nail a particularly difficult stunt. Besides that I think the game holds up rather well, in my opinion it has all the qualities of most timeless classics. The game is just fun to play, it's cheerful and loud nature just sucks you into the incredible stylistic world. Typically graphics in these older games are a non-factor but this is what I would call a special case, there's something about the aesthetic of this game that is just so infectious. There's nothing better then having one of your favorite songs come on while you grind off telephone wires and bounce in between neon signs on buildings, even picking a character you like to play the most or customizing you gangs graffiti I felt continually invested. And man does this game have style, one of the most important elements in Jet Set radio is the phenomenal soundtrack that is just so fitting and contagious. This coupled with the vibrant in your face cel-shaded art style creates a very memorable experience. So ya I would highly recommend playing Jet Set Radio, you should buy it. Also can someone tell ♥♥♥♥ing SEGA to get off their ♥♥♥ and make a HD JSRF already. Seriously wtf are they waiting for.

reviewText:
I'm giving this a positive review, and the truth is I thoroughly enjoyed it. But I feel that the flaws should be pointed out first.

- The last level of the game gave me motion sickness. For the first time I can remember, and possibly the first time ever. I am NOT prone to motion sickness, AT ALL, and the last level of this game made me want to hurl.

- The port to computer is not the best because they just directly mapped controller buttons to keyboard keys. This means that people playing on a computer have a serious disadvantage at things like graffiti, where the simple action of move the stick in a circle" becomes "hit WASDWASDWASD as fast as you can until the game decides that you did a circle instead of up-then-right-then-down-then-left separately."

- This game is extremely difficult to play with a laptop touchpad instead of a mouse. (It is playable -- just difficult.)

- The storyline was maybe a little weak? Don't play this for the storyline
recommended:
now on to the positives!

- GREAT music. A+.

- Large levels that you can spend ages exploring. Hidden paths
voteText: etc.\n\n- It's just fun! Careen down a hill
helpfulPercent: jump at the last minute

votesTotal: ride a wall sideways
votesFunny: and land in a speedy grind on a handrail. And keep going -- like I said
commentsCount: HUGE LEVELS. I'm not normally one for repetition but this game makes me want to just keep practicing and keep practicing the same courses until i can do it perfectly!\n\n- I really liked the style of the game. I thought the cel shading was very pretty."

reviewText:
What can I say about Jet Set Radio? Well it's awesome. Enough said. The graphics are very old-school and very fitting for a game like this bent on mimicing pop culture to a T. I don't know how it controls on keyboards, but I strongly reccomend playing it with an XBox 360 controller to your PC for a much better experience. The price here was a steal. $4.99 to be exact while conole versions cost about 10 bucks. For some reason, my computer beings a Windows 8 model plays it just fine. However during one cutscene the game crashed. But afterwards it never happened again.
The only thing I hate is the clunky controls when it comes to moving left or right on the ground, on ramps, or midair. But the voice acting is neat, the music is epic, the style of graphics is amazing, overall, it's an amazing game with the only flaw is the slightly off controls when it comes to moving a character. Other than that it plays just fine and I can reccomend it to anyone wishing to play another Sega masterpiece.

Now if only Jet Set Radio future could be released on Steam as well.

reviewText:
I really like this game from the music,the cel shaded graphics,and gameplay (most of it)

the gameplay consist of spray painting certain areas while avoiding cops (sometimes) under a time limit, or tagging rival gangs under a time limit.

the controls ( the key pad controls) you use wasd to move space/mouse 1 to jump mouse 2 makes  skate faster for a while and mouse wheel resets camera/ spray paint and move the mouse/jkl to control the camera, speaking of the camera.

the camera wont be your friend some times as in it gets stuck near walls, and remember the cops i mentioned,well their AI is not too bad but in bantam street the AI get really stupidand a bit unfair.

But over all this game is pretty good, 7.9/10

the reason this isn't an 8 is because the AI and camera but it has another saving grace is its price for $ 5.00 for a dreamcast game with all the good things this game is not too shabby.

Its a fun, enjoyable game and it has awesome music. The graphics are a little dated but nothing too bad. I prefer to play with a gamepad but its playable with keyboard and some patience.

reviewText: Jet Set Radio.. where do I begin with this game? One of Sega's few fantastic games for the Dreamcast, this title still holds up fantastically today. Set in the not-so-distant future, you play as members of a gang called the GGs, fighting for your own turf through skating and graffiti. This game has one of the most fantastic soundtracks I've ever heard, with fantastic gameplay and a great story to boot. It also features dozens of collectibles, for those who want to invest the time to unlock bonus graffiti, collectibles etc. The only problem I had with this game was the short length, with the main story lasting only 3-4 hours. I'd give this an 8/10, would buy at 25% sale minimum.

reviewText:
Pros:The soundtrack and graphics, of course
Fun, fairly fast-paced gameplay (though graffiti occasionally breaks the flow)
Lots and lots of unlockables
Cons:Very short story mode (about 8-9 hours), with only four levels to play

reviewText: My god did I wait forever to play his game. I already knew pretty much what I was getting into before buying beacause I had played its sequel on the original Xbox. I'm going to break this in little segmants so first let's start off with the story. Its short but funny and it does have a sort of moral lesson in the end. The music, dear lord is it amazing. There are very few games where I'll fall in love the the entire soundtrack. Each song is memorable and catchy and they fit each area very well. Even the final boss music it's great however I will admit it took some getting used to. I highly recommend you get this soundtrack on Amazon. Finally but most importantly the gameplay. Not gonna lie, the control is not the best in the world but it isn't horrible and will take some getting used to. Each area is big enough for the objective of the game and I appreaciate that each area is broken into smaller quadrents, so moving around them feels really good. There are a few instances where you wish you could go faster (slopes and rails) and the , I'll call it sprint, button just doesn't cut it. Other than that I really enjoy the game. Gives me hope that one day SEGA will release the sequel Jet Set Radio Future on steam because it corrects all the problems I have with the first game. 8/10  Also for $5 bucks its a steal.

reviewText:
DO NOT BUY THIS GAME AND EXPECT IT TO WORK IMMEDIATELY
Unfortunately, this game is currently broken to all hell due to a patch SEGA put out several years ago. No patches since 2013. Save files cannot be read, and you will find upon starting the game each time that you are at the beginning of the game. This is caused by a single mistake in capitalization in the code which is easily fixable, but SEGA won't do it. You have to do it yourself using HxD.
Really fun game, but SEGA screwed it up magnificently on the technical end.
Also, controller is a MUST. Playing this with a keyboard is a lesson in frustration.

reviewText:
A rockin' rollin' brightly-coloured platform/skate adventure through little parts of a super-styled tokyo.
Jet Set Radio's name may precede it, but it's all with good cause. Encouraging players to express their will for freedom against an oppressive regime through the use of simple acrobatic skating moves on electric/magnetic rollerblades (it's from the early noughties, they're blades, not skates, dude") and graffiti (a small minigame of matching movements when painting makes the challenge different every time).

Simple single-stick controls with triggers for paint control your character as they stick to any railed surface and grind it
recommended: like with all Dreamcast games (and games of that era) the camera can be a little moody
