reviewText:
Jet Set Radio just brings back good memories.

This classic was one of the first games to include cel-shaded rendering for a 3D game, but that doesn't do it enough justice. In Jet Set Radio, you take on the role of a group of rollerskaters in Japan, who are in this futuristic Tokyo where Jpop music and rollerskating are actually the cool thing. As part of the gameplay, you are tasked with going into neighborhoods and vandalizing them with your own Graffiti. As you start to spray onto windows and walls, the sinister police of the future will show up and try to beat you down, gas you and even shoot you. Thus, the game puts an emphasis on evading the violent cops, whilst fulfilling each level by spraying all graffiti on the walls before time runs out.

What makes this game so good? Well, it is very unique. The controls are simple and easy to become accustomed to, yet to master the game takes practice. It is thrilling because you can do stunts such as railgrinding, wallriding, etc while spraying. It is purely a sit down and have fun game, with a nice challenge. Unlike other skater games at its time, this one was less about crazy button mashing combos, and more about fluid movement. The quicker you finish, the higher the score you get. There are graffiti unlocks, and you even get to challenge other skaters to have them join your gang.

Another part of this game which is nice, is the iconic JET SET RADIO!" station which plays real pop music from Japan and the US and even England; such as punk bands

reviewText:
Cult-Classic.  Look past the weird anime style and what you've got is essentially Tony Hawk's gang wars on crack.

Quick note: It's a crappy port.  If you have a 720p monitor, either play in VSR/DSR 1080p or avoid-- the menus don't work at all in 1366x768.  Also, the game is locked to 30 FPS (game speed is tied, so no fixes), and rotating WASD takes a lot of getting used to.

Get your Xbox 360 controller and what you've got is essentially Tony Hawk when you're on shrooms.  Definitely clunky by today's standards, but the graphics hold up (mostly) and the linear set of open levels are at least a lot of fun to travel around.  Thanks to custom sprays, you can spray John Cena on cops' backs, or just use the in-game graffiti editor to spray turds and F**K DA POLICE on every wall.  Yes, just like any Source game, the abuse potential never ends...

So yes, I do recommend it still.  It still holds up pretty well with an Xbox 360 controller on hand, and once you've learned the gimmicks of the game that the godawful tutorial won't show you, there's a lot of fun to be had here.

Of course, useless memes are all the rage these days, so screw helpful reviews:

==
>A few teens are spraying grafitti on walls
>Cops and SWAT come, and start firing... GUNS... AT UNARMED TEENAGERS
10/10 too realistic

reviewText:
Pros:The soundtrack and graphics, of course
Fun, fairly fast-paced gameplay (though graffiti occasionally breaks the flow)
Lots and lots of unlockables
Cons:Very short story mode (about 8-9 hours), with only four levels to play
A few rather annoying missions (I'm looking at you, Tag Races...)
Definitely not the perfect game, but it is pretty great! It's a lot of fun to play, and is a must-have for people who enjoy awesome soundtracks.

reviewText:
Jet Set Radio remind me a lot of Sonic Adventure 1 as it is more of an experience then a game.

It has it all! Awesome totally rad music, non-sensical yet funny and somewhat fulfilling plot, clunky and hard-to-get-use-to control, beautiful aesthetic and a video game experience like no other. Well, a SEGA dreamcast game in short. Plus, Jet Set Radio was one of the first game to have cel-shaded graphic and the visual still look really great by today is stantard.

If you are looking for an innovative retro piece of art and you don't mind that your first hour in game might be awful, Jet Set Radio is for you. Be prepare though to have at least five new favorites songs.

reviewText:
This is my review of Jet Set Radio.

I first played this game when I was 11 years old. The Dreamcast was a short lived console that was greatly snubbed. I was one of the people that cherished the console and this was one of the games that I owned and played a lot. However, due to some unforeseen circumstances, the disk broke. I have wanted to play this game since then and now I have finally finished it.

Me and My Associate played through this game in one sitting, which gives you all the information about the length of this game. Getting a controller to work on this was a bit annoying at points, cutting out on us and making us restart the whole computer before the game would work. I forgot how floaty the controls were on this game. It took me about 3 hours to get the hang of it and be able to move easily. However, once I got the hang of it, I had quite a lot of fun. The music can only be described as Funkadelic, as it blasts through the Jet Set Radio. The art style is simple, yet effective and is very reminiscent of the Dreamcast Era. It was a lot of fun and I would recommend getting this game if it was on sale and take your time to enjoy it. Playing it through in one go can get a bit boring and repetitive.

Remember Dear Readers, You heard it here first. Off the record, On the QT, and very Hush-Hush.

reviewText:
Sega STILL does what Ninten STILL don't.

Having Jet set radio in my library goes to show that Sega doesn't need to make 20-30+ games of ONE series only to be successful.

Jet set Radio is a game filled with great soundtrack, original and creative characters, an interesting story, and a satisfying and intense gameplay.

If you're a 90's kid, or you're in search of a GREAT Sega classic, Jet Set Radio is the game for you.

I highly suggest this game for everyone.

reviewText:
I may not be showing much time but I have beat this version on off-line mode. I first owned this puppy on the Sega Dreamcast. Being the first 128 bit console the game and graphics stunned me back then. First the good news, this PC Steam version is exactly the same as the Dreamcast version. Now for the bad news, games today can do a heck of alot more today than the Dreamcast could ever do. Jet Set Radio just plays better in my younger memories than it does today.

Now graphics... different. The game went with cell-shading which was a first for consoles and this unique style holds up pretty good even today. Nothing that will blow your doors off compaired to today's standards but not much to disappoint either. Now the sound track is a different story all together which is fresh, hop and energenic all at once. Never have I head music get so crazy and off-beat and so enjoyable at the same time.

The story in the game is hum-ho and your missions seem off the wall but predictable this game wasn't. Unfortunately as I said before, this game played much better in my youth before I got spoiled on all the crazy games of today. I have beaten the Steam version on off-line mode but while I did, it almost felt more like work. The one thing I did love on the Dreamcast version was you could make your own 'tags' or grafetta (definite misspell) which I did from scratch but the tools on the Steam version are worse the the Dreamcast's. It's a minor point but now I can't make my own 'tags' because it takes twice as much work and it was hard to begin with.

Can I recommend this game? It's a mixed bag. I've beaten the Steam version once and don't feel like ever playing it again. On that note... no. But if you have never played it, it's a unique experience and definitely worth a playthrough once, maybe even twice. On that note, yes.

reviewText: Definitely worth a playthrough, but I'm glad I got it free. It has moments of fun that are marred by clunky charcter control in a game that at many points requires you to be precise and finish levels as fast as possible, and TANKS AND HELICOPTERS SHOOTING MISSLES AT A TEENAGER SPRAYING GRAFFITI. Seriously...the police ruin this game. If there was less of them, or less tanks and helicopters, it wouldn't be so bad. But it's a little ridiculous when you're trying to finish the last grafitti tag and you cant because youre constantly being barraged by missles. That's just stupid. That's not adding to the difficulty of the game, it's just adding unnecessary annoyance. I've heard Jet Set Radio Future makes a lot of good changes to the game, and I sincerely hope someday it's released on Steam as well. The characters, the level design, the music all have a lot of charm to them, but there's a lot of frustrating moments throughout the game from beginning to end.

reviewText:
I may not be showing much time but I have beat this version on off-line mode. I first owned this puppy on the Sega Dreamcast. Being the first 128 bit console the game and graphics stunned me back then. First the good news, this PC Steam version is exactly the same as the Dreamcast version. Now for the bad news, games today can do a heck of alot more today than the Dreamcast could ever do. Jet Set Radio just plays better in my younger memories than it does today.

Now graphics... different. The game went with cell-shading which was a first for consoles and this unique style holds up pretty good even today. Nothing that will blow your doors off compaired to today's standards but not much to disappoint either. Now the sound track is a different story all together which is fresh, hop and energenic all at once. Never have I head music get so crazy and off-beat and so enjoyable at the same time.

The story in the game is hum-ho and your missions seem off the wall but predictable this game wasn't. Unfortunately as I said before, this game played much better in my youth before I got spoiled on all the crazy games of today. I have beaten the Steam version on off-line mode but while I did, it almost felt more like work. The one thing I did love on the Dreamcast version was you could make your own 'tags' or grafetta (definite misspell) which I did from scratch but the tools on the Steam version are worse the the Dreamcast's. It's a minor point but now I can't make my own 'tags' because it takes twice as much work and it was hard to begin with.

Can I recommend this game? It's a mixed bag. I've beaten the Steam version once and don't feel like ever playing it again. On that note... no. But if you have never played it, it's a unique experience and definitely worth a playthrough once, maybe even twice. On that note, yes.

reviewText:
I don't know if the game is good or not. I couldn't get enough playtime out of it because it has a game breaking bug that doesn't allow you to save. It shows a save file but if you exit the game and start it again all your progress will be lost and if you load your save file it'll just start the game from the beginning cutscene and tutorial again. I do not recommend buying this.
Don't even waste Steam card money on it. There are games that aren't broken on Steam.

EDIT: I have been informed that there is a fix for it although doing the fix would break the Terms of Service, as it requires editing the EXE file. For now, until SEGA themselves fix this issue, I'll leave this here. But should this game be fixed, I'll edit this review and give the game a proper review.

reviewText: I never played the original game, but this is a really lazy port. The controls are awkward. The camera is awful. For some reason, the button that spray paints is also the button that centers the camera behind you, making for some crazy confusing angles, especially on the chase levels. On later levels, the maps link several places together and it's very easy to get lost or to accidentally exit the stage. Several times I got hit by a car or an enemy and shoved out of the level, which made me have to restart the whole stage. It's just not very fun. The only reason I finished it is because I was blind racing it with a friend.

reviewText: Where to begin... Anytime you hear something that sounds too good to be true, it usually is. When I see that console games from 2 generations ago are suddenly popping up all over steam, was definately a shock. I'd played JSRF years ago for the Xbox and seeing this game available on steam, I jumped at the chance to get it.\nNow, I'm begining to regret it. The whole game slows down in any large area or when there are many objects on the screen. But it's obviously not the computer's fault since the fan doesn't spin up loudly or anything. I've tried setting VSync for this game in the Nvidia control panel but that didn't seem to fix anything either. One fix claims that you install 3rd party software to limit your gpu's frames to 30fps and then the game doesn't slow down anymore.  But why should I have to do that? Something's clearly still broken here and until it's fixed, I cannot recommend this game.

reviewText:
Great Fun.

I sank hours into this game back when I had my Dreamcast and loved everything about it. I was a bit hesitant about buying it on Steam incase it would be a bad port (Crazy Taxi as a fine example) But having just bought a 360 controller for Windows, I wanted to give it a try.

I can happily say that it's a fine port, it has full controller support, widescreen support (I have it set at 1920x1080) I have not seen a single glitch in it and the graphics still look good today just like they did years ago.

The only downside to the port is its 30 frames per second cap (which would of been the same on Dreamcast) but I have found this is hardly noticeable and once you've started playing for a while it becomes the norm.

+ Good port
+ Good graphics
+ Great music
+ Really fun arcade classic

- 30fps cap

reviewText:
The concept of this game and music are great but there a few big things that bothered me right from the start:

1) It has no tutorials for keyboard and mouse. Unless you use a controller, it's pointlessly awkward to play and the first starting levels will have you button mashing to see what the npc did.

2) No obvious save. I ended up right back at the start of the tutorial twice when loading. It must be a bug with no auto-save or menu option.

3)  No sandbox mode. It would be great just to have an open sandbox version to mess around in Katamari or GTA style. Run around, mess with stuff, have fun with the music all without a timer or jarring cuts.

reviewText: Jetset Radio. Wow. What a great game, hidden beneath piles of million other popular and mainstream games in the market. I got this game free, thanks to mwnl event by sega recently. Seriously, after playing this game, i actually didnt mind to spend my money for this. Why? BCOZ THIS GAME IS FUN AS HEAVEN! The soundtracks are GREAT! They catch the theme perrfectly, combine these with extremely fun gameplay and challenging levels (well, challenging for me personally) the experience is solid. The cell shading graphic style fit the game perfectly, make it stands out among other similar games. The only things that i complain are the lack of freedom to switch song when you're playing in a level, forcing u to listen the song over and over. If u suck like me, and keep failing in one mission, the repeated song can painfully boring. Then, then i think this game need some sort of minimap, to guide player where the tags, traffics, and enemy at. The tutorial also frustating, forcing u to do insanely hard chain of tricks which must be done in a single row. However when u finally can finish it, the reward is totally worth.

reviewText:
One of my personal favorite games of all time. The controls are a bit clunky at first, but it's totally playable with a keyboard. Controller is nice if you've got one, but with some practice, it's really not that hard. I recommend starting out playing character with low graffiti levels though, so you can get used to how the graffiti works a bit better, and once you're comfortable, then move up to the higher-level graffiti characters.

**SPOILERS**

On a far less serious note, there must be zero crime in Tokyo-to for the police to send attack dogs, parachute squads, choppers, Capatin Insane-o with a gun, TANKS, and tear gas to deal with a bunch of kids... with, well, probably about eight thousand vandalism charges. And then there's the Golden Rhinos. How much money do they have? Choppers, jetpacks, all kinds of guns, flamethrowers, suicide bombers, a giant, flame-spewing golden rhino robot, and on top of all that, they have to pay their agents! It's absurd, man.

**END SPOILERS**

Overall, definitely 10/10 game. I've cleared the main story 20+ times; now I'm working on the achievements. Definitely a well-spent five bucks.

reviewText:
This game has been in my life since early childhood. My dad got me this game for the Sega Dreamcast when I was really young, but I never really got into it due to it's difficulty. I found it a while ago because of my friend, and bought it instantly. I don't regret a thing!
==PROS==
-Amazing Gameplay
-Intuitive design (who would have thought of a game where you spraypaint while getting shot by tanks?!?)
-The difficulty (Also could be a con)
==CONS==
-The controls. If you don't have a gamepad, you're gonna have a bad time. Except for me I guess. The controls don't really bother me I guess.
-Like I stated, the difficulty is INSANE!!! If you miss something, or don't see some small details, you won't be able to beat the levels. Why are tanks attacking a graffiti artist!?! Lol.
-It's not free :P
In conclusion, this game is AMAZING, but if you don't want to play a game harder than Dark Souls, then this isn't the game for you.
My Rating: 8.5/10

reviewText:
I'm revising this review after finishing the game finally, and my opinion has not changed.

Jet Set Radio to me is an example of when nostalgic blinds people into thinking old or unique premiss in games will make them automatically good.

While the graphics in this provide a colorful setting for Tokyo in many places, it starts to become a problem when the limitation of graphics in your games start to affect the actual gameplay of it. This becomes clear when trying to race in the game and the back drops give no perception of how far or close you are to an object, due to it being one image rather than separate objects. NPC models in this game are laughable when compared to the player model's graphics that it make it seems they did not even try.

One of the biggest faults in this game is the camera controls. For a game that makes you jump in very high areas, the camera will constantly clip under you. Certain times you make jumps, there will be a provided replay function, while usually this would be fine, the fact the replay happens clearly 2 seconds AFTER you make a jump, makes disorientating time when the camera goes back to the original place. This really becomes a problem when you are tying to escape mobs and the replay messes up the flow of gameplay.

The gameplay itself can be very infuriating at times, especially when games earlier than it (such as tony hawk games) nailed down the formula perfectly. This is clear when the grinding in this game is automatic rather than a dedicated button to grind, leading to mishaps in accidentally grinding when trying to jump to specific areas. There’s no way to simply dismount off of a grind either so when I try and get off I am thrusted forward into a jump instead. Jumping from curved areas is also buggy, leading to your character to either jumping straight up and doing nothing or actually performing a trick move. Stairs are also a challenge in the gameplay itself, this doesn’t becomes a problem till the later levels where you have flying enemies shooting you. When you are walking up stairs you are at the mercy of bullets hitting you with no way you to avoid getting hit, since jumping is even too slow to avoid getting it. Whoever thought the how the last level should work was a good idea  should put a bullet to their brain since platforming is this game's not strong point.

However, as many people know and what this game is known for the most. The music in this game is stealer and one of my favorite video game soundtracks ever. I can honestly say that the music is what kept me going to finally beating this.

Many people say JSRF is a better game and I am hopeful in trying it out if it improves on this game's problems  but till they release it on PC (I'm not gonna play a gimped ver on 360) Ill reserve my judgment.

reviewText:
Well that was a waste of my money, my time, and my hopes... I should have seen it coming though, videos I had watched of the game didn't lie about the floatyness of the game. Something I never ever liked in any game. But hey ! If there is good level design, it'll be all right !

Oh.

Oooooh...

Everything feels wrong abut this game. Levels are not as open as they should be, often you'll simply find yourself in a dead end with the only way to go being climbing up stairs. Which of course doesn't mesh with the skates. I might as well not have the skates for unless you're in a slope or have been grinding for a while you hardly go faster than the police officers chasing you. And you trade that modicum of speed you have on them with incredible imprecision over your direction. It's really hard to gain some speed, it's really hard to move around. The game is not snappy in the slightest.

But let's pretend you actually got some momentum. What now ? STOP. Do a graph. Just stop moving. It's time for contextual stick wiggling, harly different from a QTE. It's not very fun, but it is the objective of the game as far as I could tell from these few levels I played. In that regard, it turns the game into more of a platformer as the point is not to build speed but to jump around so that you can reach spots to graph. But again, it's so imprecise I'd rather play a genuine platformer like Sly Cooper.

There is a point system too based on how you trick, but it basically amounts to how long you grind. Which goes in direct contradiction with the tagging objectives that asks you to stop dead in your track, not that it matters considering it's useless and you'll get good grades without even trying. By that I mean that you won't feel like you deserve it and will end up thinking that good grades are actually bad. Seriously. It's that irrelevant. I don't remember any level in the fews I've played that actually recquired you to get a certain amount of points anyway. Why is it even here ?

Let's add to that unskippable cutscene, unsuprisingly dreadful camera, the police forces that feel like they waste your time more than anything else, escaping them stucks you in a cutscene everytime for no other reason but to break your flow so everything about the opposing force, be it avoiding them or escaping them, is annoying, the narrative might as well not be there...

It's not fast enough to be cathartic, it's not precise enough to be rewarding. The levels aren't open enough to give any sense of flow unless perhaps you master them but nothing makes me want to. Graphing is just there to stop you in your tracks. The obstacles on your way are more annoying than threatening. Everything feels wrong. Nothing about it is satisfying.

I want to like this game, I really do but it's all around frustrating... I don't recommend.

reviewText: Britney Spears invented anime in 2007 for her music video, Break the Ice, from her Blackout album. Anime is an animation style that exaggerates the size of the eyes and typically only represents the nose through its shadow. This animation style became incredibly popular in Japan, in part because the nation wasn’t large enough to provide the studio space required to create live-action films. Popular anime films include My Neighbor Totoro, Pokemon: The First Movie, and The Animatrix.

reviewText:
Not quite sure what to make of this. Can't seem to get the hang of the controls. Granted, it's from a different era, but I have to wonder if something got lost in the process of porting it to the PC. The funky cheerful dystopia of Japanese indie rock punk skater living is more fun to watch in anime, or imagine in art, than to actually play in this game.

So, it's a mild recommend, 5-6 out of 10, as a playable music video. Kinda frustrating as a game. I want to say the learning curve and rewards for progress are better in early Tony Hawk skating games.

Update: I changed my mind. I had to put this down as a not-recommend to balance out all the cultishly positive reviews. It's not nearly as good as the 90+ percent approval that it's getting on Steam. Again, it seems to have benefitted a lot from nostalgia, but it doesn't hold up today.

Does anyone know if it's actually fun to hang out with Japanese skater punks? Anyone?

I never had a Dreamcast or any of the early consoles, so I didn't grow up on many SEGA games. reviewText:
Don't be fooled, the real enemies in this game aren't the cops, or the rival gangs, it's the god-awful controls and camera.

Good luck tagging three enemy gang members from behind, TEN TIMES EACH, when you move the exact same speed that they do, and they always get a head start on you. Or hey, grind the edge of this ramp to make a jump onto a wire that you can't see to get to the final tagging spot, and while you're trying to make that jump, they'll zoom the camera to a cop stomping his foot in frustration at having lost you, but you'll keep flying through the air, blind, and miss it EVERY ♥♥♥♥ING TIME.

If this game didn't control like garbage and leave you blind while you struggle with the ♥♥♥♥ controls, it'd be a masterpiece. Instead, it's just something to be nostalgic about for 30 minutes and then uninstall before your nostalgia is ruined forever.

reviewText: Rollerblading has been a core part of my life for the past 12 years. I've gone through a pair a year and always had my eye on this game since its debut on the Dreamcast.\n\nI've heard Jet Set Radio Future improves the game, but unfortunately this one deserves a pass. For a skate game, the levels are oddly interruptive of flow. It's difficult in all the wrong ways, with terrible controls and poorly thought out paths that abruptly end. A small bump into level geometry (or one of those random cars) stops you solid and that's a pretty fatal flaw for a game about maintaining the flow of motion. A second earnest try at completing the game still resulted in frustration and tedium. Levels are beat based on memorization of paths rather than improvising one.

reviewText:
It's a good enough game, with an interesting subject and interesting mechanics. The controls for tagging can be tricky to execute with a keyboard though, since instead of simply spinning the joystick around, you have to press each individual directional key (which oftentimes leads to failing the tag). Overall I found the game a bit hard, in part because of the keyboard issue but also general gameplay things like how it sometimes requires very precise timing and aim. I've been told that it can take a lot of time and practice to really get into the swing of things, but until then it can be pretty frustrating.

In spite of that, I was willing to keep playing this game. The reason I can't fully recommend it is that it seems to be prone to bugs that make it impossible to play - after having played for a few months with no problems (aside from an early glitch that automatically erased my save file), the game suddenly began crashing upon startup. I've tried every fix imaginable, and none have worked so far. There seems to be 0 interest from the developpers in making any sort of patch or update, so I don't expect the situation to get any better - I'll keep trying once in a while, but I've pretty much lost hope of playing this game until I get a new computer someday (and even then, nothing's guaranteed). Obviously no game is perfect and I don't want to be too harsh when it comes to bugs, but this is the first game I've ever come across that remains completely unplayable even after trying many different fixes and the apparent indifference from the developpers is a bit discouraging.

In short, it's not a bad game at all, but there's a chance that after a while you won't be able to play it anymore with no fixes in sight - so just keep this in mind when buying, I guess.

reviewText:
I want to like this game, so so much. It's an absolute BLAST when it works - but a downright infuriating experience when it doesn't.

I've never played the games before, so I have a completely unskewed, unbiased view of it from the get go.

Jet Set Radio is a fun game, but it controls so terribly and the physics mess up so bad at times that it's neigh unplayable. Take tagging other skaters for example - you approach them to tag them, only to get smacked out of the way leading to stumble or full knockdown, to which you have to recover from and rechase. This might sound okay, but when you have to be DIRECTLY behind them to tag them, it gets grating fast since if you so much as clip them in the back even the SLIGHTEST bit, you get stumbled and they grind away only for you to have to chase them once again. It's not even difficult! It's just infuriating and unfair.

All-in-all, Jet Set Radio's 5k graphics update and gameplay live up to the test of time, but its controls and optimization do not. It's simply just a hardware limitation from when the game was developed. If the game handle better I'd instantly, undoubtedly give this game a thumbs up. But as it is now? It's just to infuriating for me to reccomend you put your time into.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Jet Set Radio is a very eccentric 90's themed game. Essentially, you play as a roller skater who skates around Tokyo-to spraying grafitti everywhere. Along the way you encounter rival gangs, people who you can compete with to join your gang, and the police. The latter plays the stereotype of extreme police brutality even just to catch some punks, using everything in their arsenal from helicopters to flamethrowers. The soundtrack has clear inspirations from 90s genres like Nu Metal, hip hop, and synthpop, among many others (my personal favorites are Miller Ball Breakers and Bout the City). The music just turns me on ;)

JSR certainly isn't lacking in originality. It's music is very diverse (as stated earlier), and it goes against the grain from many of the trends in gaming. The story in this game isn't anything to write home about, and the graphics can look really sloppy at times, but SEGA made up for it in the gameplay. The skating mechanics are very polished, and although it's easy to learn it's a very difficult game to master. It's certainly not easy, but it's not rage-inducingly hard becuase the game isn't unfair, and once you get enough practice, you can really get the hang of it. However, the gameplay was designed around using the analog stick. If you want the maximum enjoyment out of this game, definitely use a controller. Trying to input the motions for spraying graffiti is really clunky with the WASD keys, it takes a ton of getting used to, and it gets really uncomfortable after a while. It's certainly not impossible though, and you can still have fun playing it regardless (I know I did).

The amount of time it takes to finish the story line is somewhat on the short side (I play through games slowly and beat it in 10 hours). However, if you want to 100% this game and/or you want to challenge yourself to get Jet ranking on every level, I wouldn't be suprised if it was more like 100 hours because, again, it's a hard game to master. If you want replayability out of a game, I'm not very qualified to tell you, since I hardly like replaying antything.

In short, if you hate 90s culture, you'll most likely hate everything about this game. If you tend to prefer story-based games, JSR might be very forgettable. But if your preference is for gameplay, then JSR can be a really fun experience that I think you should try out.

reviewText: I don't see the appeal at all. The controls are finnicky, the physics are wonky, and one slip up makes you spend another minute or so getting back to where you were. All the levels seem to be the same thing; run away from the police, tag over some other gang's tags and finish the level before time's up or you die. Some of the design choices are terrible. Jumping and doing a trick shouldn't be the same button, as doing a trick sends you significantly higher in the air than a regular jump does. I guess this is the power of nostalgia but as someone who's coming to this in 2016 I'm not impressed, and no, it's not just because it's old.

reviewText:
When Jet Set Radio debuted on the Dreamcast in North America as Jet Grind Radio back in 2000, it offered a unique experience that no other console game of that era could match. Players stepped into the skates of energetic graffiti artists residing in the fictional city of Tokyo-to. The goal was to tag as much of the landscape as possible with colorful graffiti designs, a task made difficult by the presence of rival gangs that were attempting to do the exact same thing--and by a police force that believed the best punishment for such vandalism was death by guided missile. The only way to stay ahead of the threats was to keep cruising and grinding, leaping from one point to another and pausing only just long enough to spray an intricate tag before resuming the crazy rush.

Graffiti may be artwork, but don’t forget: it’s also a crime!

Jet Set Radio relies heavily on its presentation and it doesn’t always stress the details. Stages end abruptly once you tag all available points (marked by red arrows), not when you achieve a certain score or defeat a challenging boss. The energetic beats looping in the background and the vibrant cel-shaded visuals have always been the primary reasons to keep playing, and those elements are especially effective now that all of the familiar artwork has been upgraded for high-definition televisions. Most of the original music also returns. Players discovering the game in 2012 may wonder what they’re missing, though, because there’s not a lot to savor beyond the funky presentation.

Jet Set Radio's most regrettable issue is its simple but somehow ineffective control setup. As your skater cruises through the various areas, even the simple act of skating in a straight line can sometimes prove difficult if you're not grinding a railing, because you have to hold the analog stick forward to build speed. The tiniest nudge of the analog stick can wreak havoc, since your skating graffiti artist is prone to wide sweeping movements rather than more precise motions. Yet if you need to change direction slightly while flying through the air (usually because your skater launched unexpectedly toward one side or the other rather than pushing forward in the anticipated straight line), fiddling with the analog stick often has almost no effect at all.

The rails you must frequently grind also lack stickiness, which makes landing on them at the end of a leap a tricky proposition. You may overshoot your intended destination, and that often means you must backtrack through hazardous territory so that you can make another attempt. Building up speed so that you can manage the long jumps required to clear gaps is also an issue, since by default your skater moves at a snail's pace. You're forced to pay entirely too much attention to the controls the whole time you play, lest a split second of inattentiveness lead to disaster.

Getting around Tokyo-to can be a bit of a grind.

The inadequate camera does nothing to alleviate such control issues, either. Many of the environments are practically barren until enemies begin appearing in response to your vandalism, but you still stumble across a few unwelcome piles of debris in the most inconvenient of places, or perhaps a series of vehicles parked along a street between you and a wall that you need to tag. The camera gets stuck on objects in confined spaces, jerks crazily if you're following a path through a winding corridor, or spins in such a way that you can't see environmental obstacles that in any other game would be easily spotted. The only way to make crucial runs in some stages is to first memorize their layouts through trial and error.

In some instances, you also must tag objects with precise timing, but since the left trigger serves two functions, it's easy to accidentally start messing with the camera instead of tagging the environment as you may have intended. Such goofs delay your ability to paint for a brief moment, which is time enough that you sometimes miss spraying a target that you should easily have been able to tag on the fly.

Instead of finding ways to alleviate the camera and control issues, the game's original developers at Smilebit used those flaws as a means of providing additional challenge. In one stage, for instance, your chosen skater must race along an arcing passageway, then leap onto a narrow and winding ledge, ride it along an S path, and finally leap over a balcony to land on a narrow bit of piping that when viewed from a distance blends in with the background. This scenario would be fun but not especially challenging in a game with responsive controls and a friendly camera, but in Jet Set Radio it is a chore. Building up speed requires a rush down a corridor with horrible visibility, and the leap from one construction beam to another requires that you guess properly about the precise positioning of a rail that often is off-camera.

The game has no shortage of great tunes, and the kooky DJ is still fun.

In a few other stages, your skater's goal is to tag members of a rival gang with paint. The environments where you must do so are built to slow you down at every turn. In the first such mission, the cowardly goons skate along a sewer pathway that includes stairs, pools of murky water, and an enclosed passage that is littered with piles of immovable barrels and equipped with a trapdoor in the floor. Your job is to direct your skater as he or she races after those foes--who all move with an easy grace that most human players will never reproduce with their skaters--and spray them from behind several times. Until you memorize the stage layout in its entirety (along with the route your rivals follow), you don't stand a chance.

Not every stage is frustrating in the same way, and there are moments when you find yourself having some fun, but each new environment presents an exasperating wrinkle of some sort. The most common stage objective simply asks your skater to roam around and tag key areas while avoiding an ever-increasing police presence. Such levels begin with almost no resistance at all, which gives you time to gather paint cans (since your graffiti-loving skater always starts with none on hand). After you tag a few locations, though, you have to avoid tear gas, dogs, SWAT teams, a trigger-happy captain, helicopters that fire missiles, and other similar hazards. That had the potential to be exciting, but the finicky controls and ineffective camera make it difficult to track the location of your enemies until they're pelting you with bullets, grenades, or missiles.

As if the control and camera issues weren't bad enough, sometimes you may also find yourself accidentally exiting stages. The city environments you explore have invisible boundaries, and you receive a warning if you're about to pass one. However, no barrier prevents you from actually doing so. You are simply taken to the level selection menu. So if you're most of the way through a stage, an onscreen arrow indicator might be pointing you toward a point that you need to tag, and it may direct you along a path that leads you near an exit. Then you could get hit by a car or an explosive blast and knocked out of bounds before you have a chance to recover.

Jet Set Radio doesn't feel as much like a game as it does a test of endurance. Entertainment options have come a long way since 2000, and consumers now take smooth controls and a capable camera system for granted. Most gamers will find little joy in the outdated design elements that so thoroughly color this particular experience, even if they are in the mood for something retro. While the game was once an interesting way to pass the time, its value has expired, and a shinier coat of paint doesn't change that.

The Good
Prettier than ever
Funky soundtrack

The Bad
Touchy controls
Inept camera
Frustrating stage design

4.5
Poor

reviewText:
As sad as I am to say this, the game concept is still really cool and I like the characters and the music, but everything else, not anymore.
Back in the days, at the Dreamcast era, the game felt incredible.
Nowaday after many years of video game science achieved and honed, the game feels horrible in my hands.

Every gameplay mechanics is a mess because of poor balancing/polishing.
* You're never able to tell where you should go, and you've got dozen of checkpoints to meet (drawing a map through try-and-die was and still is an unacceptable mechanic).
* You're never able to fight. You're against invicible NPCs which teleports near you when they desire to do so. (exception for 1 NPC out of 10 which you can get rid of by...tagging it)
* Same remark for challenges from the GG clan : why a big 120Kgs guy (you) is repulsed violently just by touching a small fry.
* You can actually quit a mission by going the wrong way in a map (it can happen extremly quickly by being crashed by a car)

If from above all, you cumulate :
* Horrible controls : everything is based on keeping the momentum but when you return to slow speed, the game feels extremly unsatisfactory to play and feels unresponsive.
* outdated menus handling (they do not feel smooth when using it)
* poor accessiblity  : you'll love to return to the garage to restart a f---ed up mission, instead of having a simple restart choice.
* outdated graphics : the cell shading is still nice and the low poly gives it some pedigree but the textures sure would require a bit of rework, as well as the draw distance.

reviewText:
Playing Jet Set Radio today will make you rethink your love for the Dreamcast. Its levels are cramped, crowded, and a chore to navigate. It was released a year after Tony Hawk, yet in contrast to that game its sluggish controls make you feel like the game is constantly working against you.

Ah, but the soundtrack, right?

Oh, the soundtrack. It's novel, but that's the most that can be said. At its best it's repetitive, and at its worst, it's like listening to a bawling baby. With a megaphone. Look, I've often played the same game for dozens of hours with the same music playing over and over the whole time. After only an hour with JSR, I was searching for the option to cut that noise off.

At least the graphics are nice. No, I'm serious about that. But that's about it.

reviewText: When gamers talk about classics on the Dreamcast, Jet Set Radio is a title that is often brought up with misty-eyed nostalgia. The vibrant visuals, diverse soundtrack and anarchic spirit struck a chord with critics and fans back in the day. Unfortunately, while the the art direction and audio still hold up remarkably well, the gameplay doesn't. Most missions consist of you spraying graffiti over a designated number of hotspots in an area within a certain amount of time. So far so okay, but once you've sprayed a certain amount of graffiti, the police come and make completing the mission an exercise in tedium and frustration. Other missions task you with copying a rival skater's moves, racing them, or spraying them with enough graffiti. The controls and camera just aren't tight enough for the demanding challenges that the game throws at you. You'd think that with such a lack of precision that the game would be a tad forgiving towards minor mistakes. That's not the case. One jump a little too far, one minor bump against a wall, or one little brush against your opponent can cause you to fail. There's no option to restart a mission if things aren't going well; you have to either wait for your opponent to beat you, or go back to the garage and go though the entire mission briefing all over again. Completing these tasks feels laboring when it should feel fun, clunky when it should feel tight, and frustrating when it should feel liberating. If you loved the original, these objections won't matter to you. If you haven't played this game, I'd recommend you check out either the superior Jet Set Radio Future or Tony Hawk Pro Skater.

reviewText:
This game has an absolutely fantastic soundtrack, and cool cel shaded graphics.
However, it is old, and it hasn't aged well.
It can be very difficult and frustrating, and it doesn't feel fair. The game is hard because the controls are stupid and not responsive enough.
You'll find yourself looking up videos of gameplay because you can't beat levels and you don't know why.
Also there's no open world at all, just set levels with predetermined goals. It would have been fun to just cruise around doing tricks and exploring. Run over time or out of health and you have to start again.
Note that the top positive reviews are old fans of the game, and they are actually asking for the sequel to this game to get ported.
Looks great, sounds great, controls are crap (even if you have a controller, which I do).
Very frustrating and annoying. Not worth the sale price. Go play an old Tony Hawk's game instead.

reviewText: My Grandfather smoked his whole life. I was about 10 years old when my mother said to him, 'If you ever want to see your grandchildren graduate, you have to stop immediately.'. My mother said to me- 'Don't ever smoke. Please don't put your family through what your Grandfather put us through. I agreed. At 28
date: I have never touched a cigarette. I must say
recommended: I feel a very slight sense of regret for never having done it
hoursPlayed: because this port of an otherwise great game gave me cancer anyway."

reviewText: I absolutely loved Jet Set Radio Future, so it's disheartening to realise the predecessor isn't anything like it. Jet Set Radio is one of the most frustrating games when it comes to floaty controls and confusing, obfuscated game design. Avoid it unless you're playing it for the nostalgia and absolutely do not buy it if you do not have a controller as it's almost unplayable on kb+m. Here's hoping JSRF also gets ported one day, it's the superior game in every way.\n\nEdit: It's discouraging to see all of these reviews with legitimate concerns being thumbed down only for reviews with a few basic words of approval achieving such a high rating. Goes to show just how flawed Steam's system currently operates.

reviewText:
I never played this, so I have no nostalgia goggles.

The controls feel awful, don't even bother with a keyboard, it's such a pain.
I don't like the music, but it's just background noise, so I'm not docking points.
I don't like the style, but I like that it's constant... except for that cop's face... but the DJ's chin clipping through his body as he talked was pretty inexcusable... especially since it was the only thing catching your eye, moving the most.
then the story expects us to accept some public menace punks are the heroes while some power-mad police are the villains... No. Nonono. Both groups are villains. The only people that aren't damaging public property and blasting people's ears with loud noise ARE THE BYSTANDERS WHO DON'T AFFECT THE STORY. They are the only good guys.
The gameplay has you fleeing from an arsenal you should never have to face as a non-violent CHILD character... WHAT THE FRICK, GUYS.
... Looking at the 'key features' up there... it even knows this game sucked. 'NOW ON PC! IN HD! We put in some fan junk! We took a track out! Make your own graffiti in our old system! NO WE WON'T UPDATE IT LIKE WE SHOULD. Play as more than one char while the story doesn't care!!' THOSE ARE NOT FEATURES ANY MORE. THEY ARE TOTALLY EXPECTED, AND YOU DID IT WRONG.

TLDR
Music; Meh.
Style; Meh.
Gameplay and controls; BAD.
Story and cutscenes; BAD.
Sales pitch; HORRIBLE.

If you never played this as a kid, DO YOURSELF A FAVOR, AND JUST DON'T.

reviewText:
imagine this: you're the greatest skater in the world i mean you're like tony hawk but without that stupid licensed skateboard game (you know the one the one with the real skateboard that everybody hates) and you're gettin your game on in a beautiful cel-shaded city and you're going crazy and jumping from rail to rail and skating all over the place and evading the cops like a badass

now imagine that same scene only the first time you try to jump from one rail to another your character suddenly screams YEAH and jumps 20 feet over the rail you were trying to jump to and you faceplant into a wall

that's basically jet set radio

reviewText:
What I got to see in less than 30 minutes:

- Boring music
- Poor animations
- Gamplay based in 4 buttons with no convinations between them
- Extremely limited stages
- Boring objectives: Draw graffitis everywere without being caught

It was just a first impressions but first impressions in game counts (for me) and it was bad.

Thankfully, I got it for free :)

reviewText: Sometimes I like to think some games make better movies than games. Jet Set Radio is a game that is a better mixtape than it is a game, mostly due in part to its controls. Now, the nostalgists will whine about how the awful controls are part of the experience! But this is encouragement on their part to give SEGA a pass on ♥♥♥♥ controls, and they're just as bad now as they are then. So ♥♥♥♥ nostalgists and ♥♥♥♥ SEGA for not fixing the controls. Listen to the soundtrack instead.

According to all known laws
of aviation,


there is no way a bee
should be able to fly.


Its wings are too small to get
its fat little body off the ground.


The bee, of course, flies anyway


because bees don't care
what humans think is impossible.


Yellow, black. Yellow, black.
Yellow, black. Yellow, black.


Ooh, black and yellow!
Let's shake it up a little.

Ooming!

Hello?

- Adam?

Looking sharp.

paid good money for those.


Sorry. I'm excited.


Here's the graduate.
We're very proud of you, son.

Very proud.

Never thought I'd make it.

three days high school.

a day and hitchhiked around the hive.

reviewText:
Note: the current build of this game contains an error that prevents saved games from loading. A fix can be downloaded from the forum.

Also, you really need a controller for this one.

Okay, you know this is one of the most stylish action games out there, with a legendary soundtrack and a great theme brought home by some of the earliest and best use of cel shaded graphics. However, this game is often criticized for having annoying enemies and being frustrating and awkward to control, and in larger city sections the zones are connected with clever but rather silly design workarounds that take some experimentation to navigate.  Ultimately though, the cops are dangerous, the controls are like learning to roller blade, and traversing the levels feels like exploring a living, breathing world.

Next time you feel like writing a diatribe about design conveyance, in-game tutorials, or how you're giving up on gaming"
date: you should probably just step back
hoursPlayed: and play some Jet Set Radio. This is a true classic that hasn't aged a bit in three generations
voteText: and it's on your computer now. With right analog camera control. That's freaking special."

reviewText:
A true classic for those who have played the original on the Dreamcast.

The game is even better in HD and plays smoothly with a PS3 controller hooked up. For those gamers who are into highly stylish cel-shaded graphics, unique soundtrack (a mix of house/hiphop/bossa nova/funk), and fast-reaction gameplay, this is recommended for you. Music / gameplay / graphics are all preserved in the PC-port.

5 out of 5 stars.

After a little time with the game I learned how to manage the jankiness, and had a lot of fun with it. Also, the soundtrack is perfect.

reviewText: First playthrough is very fun, but short. It has an amazing soundtrack and an interesting visual style. Don't go into this game looking for more than a very average skating game, though. It has a story that makes absolutely no sense, the control takes some getting used to, and many enemy attacks cannot be avoided. It lacks replayability aswell, unless you enjoy tedious tasks in a very small amount of areas. It is just a port of a Dreamcast game, too. The textures aren't updated at all, the draw distance is terrible (rather, the game only loads a small chunk of an entire level at a time, causing pop in for other chunks), and the camera is still garbage. It adds nothing new but a couple of new graffiti souls to spray and a movie you could just watch on youtube. For all of these complaints, it's still surprisingly fun and engaging. Get it if it's on sale, it's an okay game but nothing amazing.

reviewText:
Pros:

Extreamly unique title retextured and optimised for modern expectations on PC
Great soundtrak, and a great implementation of cel-shaded graphics.

Cons:

Game doenst save properly, there is a workaround posted on the community page that is easy to implement but shows lack of effort by Blit Software who ported the game
Some parts of the game can be confusing to figure out, one level in particular has you run through what looks like a void zone in the level (a wall textured to look like a street, all other isntances of this exit the level) when in fact you need to run through it and then skate around in an awkward camera angle helplessly untill you find the next area.

It's still a very unique and fun game, well worth the $4.99 pricetag, heres hoping SEGA gives us a JSRF port sometime in the future.

reviewText:
This game is awesome and addicting! The music magnificent, gameplay is fun and satasfying, (but after playing the game a second time, I ran into some frame rate issues, but that might be just be a problem on my part), The game looks nice in HD, and some songs from Jet Set Radio Future (By the way, please port JSRF to today's hardware SEGA!) are included as a nice bonus.

The one thing I wish that was in the game was a way to import pictures (Not using graffiti manager) as graffiti. Also, the currunt version of the game has a game breaking bug in the EXE that makes it so when you load your save file, it starts you back from the very begining of the game (no matter where you are in the game). But, people have fixed it themselfs (SEGA has yet to realease a patch or anything). Also, YOU MUST PLAY THIS WITH A CONTROLER. The game is almost unplayable without it.

If you don't want to deal fixing this bug yourself, or deal with getting your controller to work on PC, and don't mind spending a little more for the game, Go and get one of the other ports of the game (It's on PS3, PSVita, and Xbox 360).  Other than that, this port is OK (once you fix the bug, and get the controler working on the PC, It's an awesome)

As a port, in it's current state, it gets a 6.5 spraycans out of 10 for the game breaking bug and playing with the keybord and mouse is hell.

As a game though, I give the game 9.4 spraycans out of 10, would spray up tokyo-to again, and again. (Not Grind City. Those levels suck. ♥♥♥♥ Grind City)
